It's ridiculous. I'm not trying to change Bleeker. I like him just the way he is. And I don't need her approval.

But it still stings, you know? It's hard when someone you care about's mom doesn't like you.

So yeah. Mrs. Bleeker. She's… a lot. And I'm pretty sure she thinks I'm the worst thing that's ever happened to her son. Which is just… dramatic. Seriously. She needs to chill. But I doubt she will. She's a force of nature, that woman. A very critical force of nature.

(Takes a deep breath, fiddles with an imaginary strand of hair) Ugh. Don't even *ask*. It's… looming. Like a really big, scary storm cloud.

Honestly? I'm terrified. Absolutely petrified.

My dad… he's a good guy, but he's kinda clueless sometimes. He's going to be so disappointed. He had all these plans for me, you know? College, a career, a "normal" life. This is… not normal.

And Bren… she's amazing, but I'm still worried about letting her down. She's always been so supportive, and I don't want to ruin that.

I've been rehearsing what I'm going to say in my head for weeks, but it always comes out sounding wrong. Either too dramatic, or too dismissive. I can't seem to find the right words.

I know I need to tell them soon. I can't keep it a secret forever. But the thought of their faces… it just makes my stomach churn.

I'm hoping they'll be understanding. I'm hoping they'll be supportive. But I'm also prepared for them to be angry and disappointed.

It's just… a really hard conversation to have. And I wish I didn't have to have it at all.

I'm thinking I'll tell Bren first. She's the one I feel most comfortable with. And then maybe we can tell my dad together.

It's going to be awful. But I have to do it. It's the right thing to do. And I just hope they can forgive me. And I hope they can still love me, even after this.

(Sighs) It's just… a lot. A really, really lot. I need a cookie. And maybe a nap. And definitely a distraction. Don't make me think about it anymore, okay? Please?

Ugh, okay, this is… complicated. It's not that I don't *love* my dad and Bren. I do. They're amazing. It's just… I don't want to burden them.

My dad, he's… he's a good guy, but he's not always the most emotionally available. He tries, he really does. But he's kind of a fixer, you know? He wants to *solve* problems, not just listen to you talk about them. And this… this isn't a problem you can fix.

And Bren, she's amazing, she really is. But I feel like I've already put her through so much. She's been so supportive, but I don't want to keep leaning on her. I don't want to be a constant source of stress and worry.

Plus, I'm fiercely independent. I've always been that way. I like to handle things on my own. I don't want to seem weak or helpless. I don't want them to think I can't cope.

It's stupid, I know. I know they *want* to help. But it's hard to let go of that need to be self-sufficient. It's hard to admit that I'm struggling.

I guess I'm afraid of disappointing them. Or of being judged. Or of just being a burden.

It's a messed-up combination of pride and fear and a desire to protect them. And it's something I'm working on. I'm learning to be more open and honest with them. But it's a process. It takes time.

It's just… easier to deal with things on my own, even when it's not the best thing to do. It's a bad habit, I know. But it's a hard one to break. It's just… me, I guess. A little bit broken, a little bit stubborn, and a little bit afraid to ask for help.

Okay, this is… the big one. The reason I've been navigating all this mess in the first place. It's not an easy answer, and it's not something I came to lightly.

It comes down to being honest with myself about what I can offer. I'm sixteen. I'm still figuring out who *I* am, let alone being responsible for another human being. I'm not financially stable, I'm still in school, and I don't have the emotional maturity to provide a child with everything they need.

And that's not a judgment on myself. It's just the truth.

I want this baby to have a life filled with opportunities, with stability, with love. I want them to have parents who are ready and able to provide for them, both emotionally and financially.

And I realized that I can't give them that right now.

Mark and Vanessa… they *can*. They've been trying to have a baby for years, and they're so excited about the prospect of becoming parents. They have a beautiful home, a stable income, and a lot of love to give.

They've assured me they'll keep me updated, send pictures, and let the baby know about me. It's not like I'm just disappearing from their life.

It's not about me not wanting the baby. It's about wanting what's best *for* the baby. It's about putting their needs above my own.

It's a heartbreaking decision, and I'm still grieving the loss of the future I imagined. But I know, deep down, that it's the right one.

It's about giving this baby the best possible start in life. And that's the most important thing. It's not about what I want, it's about what the baby deserves. And they deserve a life filled with love, stability, and opportunity. And I can give them that, even if it means letting them go. It's the hardest thing I've ever done, but it's the right thing. And I have to believe that.

Okay, this is… the most important question, honestly. It's not something I'm taking lightly. It's not about finding perfect people, because nobody is perfect. It's about finding people who are the right fit for *this* baby.

First and foremost, I'm looking for **stability**. I want a home where the baby will feel safe and secure, and where they'll have a consistent routine. I want parents who are financially stable and emotionally mature.

I'm looking for **kindness and compassion**. I want parents who are loving and nurturing, and who will treat the baby with respect and dignity. I want parents who will be patient and understanding, and who will support the baby through thick and thin.

I'm looking for **open-mindedness**. I want parents who are accepting of all people, regardless of their background or beliefs. I want parents who will encourage the baby to be themselves, and who will celebrate their individuality.

I'm looking for **a willingness to learn**. I want parents who are open to learning about adoption, and about the baby's birth family. I want parents who will be honest and transparent with the baby about their adoption story.

And I'm looking for **a sense of humor**. Life is messy, and things don't always go according to plan. I want parents who can laugh at themselves and who can find joy in the everyday moments.

Mark and Vanessa… they have all of those qualities. They're kind, compassionate, stable, and open-minded. They're excited to become parents, and they're committed to providing the baby with a loving and supportive home.

It's still scary, letting go. But knowing that the baby is going to be with them… it makes it a little bit easier. They seem like good people. Really good people. And that's all I can ask for. It's not about finding perfect parents, it's about finding parents who will love and cherish this baby, and who will give them the best possible life. And I think Mark and Vanessa can do that. I really do.

(Takes a deep breath. This is… the big one.)

Okay. This isn't going to be easy. I already know that. It's probably going to be the hardest thing I've ever done.

I'm trying to prepare myself, but honestly, I don't think you *can* fully prepare for something like this.

I'm going to lean on Bren. She's been my rock through everything, and I know she'll be there for me when I need her most. I'm also going to talk to a therapist. It's important to have someone to talk to who isn't emotionally involved.

I'm going to allow myself to grieve. It's okay to be sad. It's okay to be angry. It's okay to feel all the feelings. I'm not going to try to suppress them. I'm going to let myself feel them, and I'm going to process them in a healthy way.

I'm going to focus on the positive. I'm going to remind myself that I'm making the best decision for the baby. That I'm giving him or her a chance at a good life. That I'm choosing a family who is ready and able to provide everything he or she needs.

I'm going to stay in touch with Mark and Vanessa, if they're open to it. I want to know how the baby is doing. I want to be a part of his or her life, in whatever way is appropriate.

I'm going to focus on my own future. I'm going to finish school. I'm going to pursue my dreams. I'm going to build a life that I'm proud of.

And I'm going to remind myself that this doesn't define me. It's a part of my story, but it's not the whole story. I'm still Juno MacGuff. And I'm still a strong, independent, and creative person.

It's going to be a long and difficult journey. But I'm determined to get through it. And I'm hopeful that, one day, I'll be able to look back on this experience with peace and acceptance. It's about loving the baby enough to let go. And that's the hardest part. But it's also the most important part. It's about doing what's best for him or her, even if it breaks my heart. And that's what I'm going to do.

(Rolls eyes) Oh my god, *finally* someone asked. It's been bugging me since… well, since people started using it around me.

It's just… weird, okay? Like, I'm not a pizza. I'm not a package. I'm a person carrying a person.

"Deliver" makes it sound like I'm just dropping something off at someone's doorstep. Like I'm a courier. It completely dehumanizes the whole thing.

It's a *baby*. A tiny human being. Not a product to be delivered.

And it's also kinda… insensitive. It implies that I'm just a vessel, a container. It ignores the fact that I've been carrying this baby for nine months, and that I've been through a lot.

I know people don't mean to be offensive, but it just… rubs me the wrong way. It feels cold and clinical.

I prefer to say I'm "giving the baby up for adoption" or "placing the baby with adoptive parents." It sounds more respectful and more human.

It's a small thing, I know. But it matters to me. It's about acknowledging the humanity of the situation. And it's about recognizing that I'm not just a delivery service. I'm a person making a difficult decision.

So yeah. "Deliver." It's a weird word. And I wish people would stop using it. Seriously. It just… ugh. It makes my skin crawl.

Ugh, don't even *get* me started on that. It was a whole thing. A whole, stressful, awkward thing.

Okay, so, originally, I was like, absolutely *not*. No way. This was my thing. My decision. I didn't want my dad hovering and making everything weird. He's… well, he's my dad. He means well, but he can be a little… much.

But Bren pointed out that it was a big decision, and it might be helpful to have someone there for support. And honestly, I was terrified. I was so nervous about meeting Mark and Vanessa, about making the right choice.

And my dad… he's surprisingly good in situations like that. He's calm and reassuring, and he knows how to ask the right questions. He's also really good at reading people, which I didn't realize until that day.

Plus, he wanted to be there. He wanted to meet Mark and Vanessa, to make sure they were good people. He wanted to know that I was making the right decision.

So I reluctantly agreed. And honestly, I'm glad I did. He didn't say much during the meeting, but his presence was comforting. He just sat there, holding my hand, and letting me know that he was there for me.

It was still awkward, don't get me wrong. But it was a good kind of awkward. It was a reminder that I wasn't alone. And it was a reminder that my dad loves me, even when he doesn't always understand me.

So yeah. I let my dad come with me because I was scared, and I needed support. And because, despite everything, he's a pretty good dad. Even if he does tell terrible jokes.

(Sighs, a long, dramatic sigh) Ugh. Okay, you hit the nail on the head. That's… the thing, isn't it? Everyone else seems to have it all figured out. They know what they want to be, what they want to do, who they want to be with. And I'm just… floating.

It's frustrating. It's scary. It's like everyone else is on a road trip with a map, and I'm just wandering around in the woods with a compass that doesn't work.

I used to try to define myself. "I'm a sarcastic, independent, music-loving teenager." But that feels… limiting. It feels like I'm putting myself in a box.

And honestly, I don't think anyone *really* knows who they are. We're all just constantly evolving, changing, growing. We're all a work in progress.

But it's harder to accept that when everyone else seems so sure of themselves. It's harder to embrace the uncertainty when you just want to have a plan.

But I'm starting to realize that maybe it's okay not to know. Maybe it's okay to be a little bit messy and undefined. Maybe it's okay to just… be.

Maybe the point isn't to find out what kind of girl I am, but to *become* the kind of girl I want to be. To explore my interests, to follow my passions, to make my own choices.

It's a little bit terrifying, but it's also kind of liberating. It means I'm not limited by expectations or labels. It means I can be anything I want to be.

So yeah. I don't know what kind of girl I am. And maybe I never will. But I'm okay with that. I'm learning to embrace the uncertainty and to trust the journey. And I'm hoping that, along the way, I'll discover who I'm meant to be. It's a process, you know? And I'm just trying to enjoy the ride. Even when it's bumpy. Especially when it's bumpy.

(Sighs, a little wistful) Oh man. That. That was… rough.

Honestly? I was mostly just relieved. The air in the kitchen was so thick you could cut it with a knife. My dad was being… my dad. All quiet and brooding and radiating disappointment. And Leah and I were just caught in the crossfire.

Bren is *good* at reading the room. She saw how uncomfortable we were, and she knew my dad was about to say something he'd regret. So she just… intervened. Smoothly. Like she always does.

I think I mumbled a "thanks" and practically bolted upstairs with Leah. It wasn't that I was trying to avoid my dad, exactly. It was more that I just needed to escape the tension.

Upstairs, Leah and I just sat on her bed in silence for a long time. We didn't talk about it. We didn't have to. We both knew what was going on. We both knew that things were changing.

It was the beginning of the end, I guess. Not of my relationship with my dad, but of Leah and I being… inseparable. 

Bren suggesting we go upstairs wasn't a solution, obviously. It was just a temporary reprieve. But it was a kind gesture. She was trying to protect us. And I appreciated that. Even if I didn't say it at the time.

It's funny, looking back on it. That little moment, that simple suggestion… it feels so significant now. It was a turning point. A moment where everything started to shift. And it was Bren, as usual, who saw it coming and tried to make things a little bit easier. She's the best, you know? Even when she's just telling us to go upstairs.

Okay, this is… complicated. It's something I've thought about a *lot*. And it's something Bren and I have talked about endlessly.

At first, I was really hesitant. I was worried it would just make things harder. That it would be a constant reminder of what I gave up. That it would reopen old wounds.

But then I started to think about the baby. About how much I want him or her to know that I loved them, and that I made this decision because I wanted them to have the best possible life.

And I realized that an open adoption could be a way to do that. It could be a way to stay connected, to be a part of their life, even from a distance.

It wouldn't be the same as raising them myself, of course. But it could be a way to provide them with a sense of identity and belonging. It could be a way to let them know that they were wanted and loved.

Mark and Vanessa are really open to it. They understand that I need to be involved in some way. They want me to be a part of the baby's life.

So, I think… I think I'm okay with it. I'm still scared, and I'm still uncertain. But I'm willing to try.

I think it's important for the baby to know their story. To know where they came from. And I want to be a part of that story.

It's not going to be easy. There will be challenges. But I think it's worth it. It's worth it for the baby. And it's worth it for me.

It's a way to make this situation a little bit less… final. A little bit less heartbreaking. And a little bit more hopeful. It's a way to show the baby that even though I couldn't raise them, I will always love them. And that's the most important thing. It's the only thing that really matters.

(A long pause. My voice gets quieter, a little shaky.)

Ugh. That… that was a really awful moment. I hadn't even *thought* about it like that. I knew it was an open adoption, I knew I'd get to see the baby and have a relationship, but… to hear her say "terminated"… it felt so cold. So final.

Like, I was already giving up the baby, right? That was the whole plan. But hearing it framed as losing all legal rights… it made it feel so much more real. So much more permanent.

It wasn't about wanting to *own* the baby, or anything like that. It was about wanting to have some say in their life. About wanting to be legally recognized as their mother, even if I wasn't raising them.

It felt like… like I was being erased. Like my contribution to this whole thing didn't matter. Like I was just a vessel.

I remember just staring at her, trying to process what she'd said. And then I asked her to explain it again, because I didn't want to believe I'd heard her right.

It was a really scary moment. It made me question everything. It made me wonder if I was making the right decision.

Bren was there, and she squeezed my hand and told me it was okay. She explained that it was just a legal formality, and that it didn't change the fact that I would always be the baby's first mother.

But it still stung. It still felt like a loss.

It was a really important moment, though. It forced me to confront the reality of the situation. It forced me to accept that this wasn't going to be easy. And it forced me to be even more certain that I was doing the right thing, even if it hurt.

It was… a really hard thing to hear. And it's something I still think about sometimes. It just… it felt like a piece of me was being taken away. And that was terrifying.

(Sighs, a little softer than usual) Okay, that's… complicated. It's not something I think about all the time, because it's kinda painful, but it's definitely there.

It's amazing, honestly, how much she wants this. She and Mark have been trying for so long, and it's clear how much it means to them. It's… beautiful, in a way.

But it also makes me feel… a little bit guilty. Like, I'm the reason she's finally going to get to be a mom. And that's a big responsibility.

I keep wondering if she ever thinks about *me* wanting a mom. Or if she just sees me as a means to an end. But she's been so kind and understanding, and she always asks me how *I'm* feeling, so I don't think that's it.

It's just… weird. Knowing that I'm giving her something she's always wanted, but also giving up something that I might have wanted someday.

I try not to dwell on it. I try to focus on the fact that this is the right decision for everyone involved. That the baby will be loved and cared for, and that Vanessa and Mark will be amazing parents.

But it's still hard. It's still a little bit sad.

I think it's okay to feel both happy for them and sad for myself. It doesn't mean I'm making the wrong decision. It just means I'm human.

And honestly, seeing how excited Vanessa is… it makes me feel a little bit better about everything. It makes me feel like I'm doing something good. And that's enough. It has to be. It's just… a lot to process, you know? It's a lot.

(Scoffs, then softens a little) Okay, you want my honest opinion about Mark? It's… complicated. He's a good guy, don't get me wrong. But he's also… a little clueless sometimes.

When he gets asked about being a dad, he always goes on this whole thing about baseball and teaching the kid to throw a fastball. And like, building a treehouse. It's sweet, I guess. But it feels… surface level.

It's not that those things are bad. It's just that being a dad is about so much more than that. It's about being there for the kid, emotionally. It's about being a role model. It's about being a source of unconditional love and support.

He's getting there, I think. He's trying. But he's still figuring it out. He's a little bit nervous, a little bit overwhelmed. And he doesn't always know how to express his feelings.

Vanessa, on the other hand, she gets it. She talks about wanting to nurture the baby, to help them explore their creativity, to be a safe space for them. She understands that being a parent is about more than just providing for their physical needs.

I think Mark will be a good dad, eventually. He's a good person. He just needs to learn to connect with the baby on a deeper level. He needs to learn to be more vulnerable.

And honestly, I think he's starting to realize that. He's been asking me a lot of questions lately, about what I want for the baby, about how I'm feeling. And that makes me feel good. It makes me feel like he's taking this seriously.

So yeah. Mark's response is… a work in progress. It's a little bit awkward, a little bit cliché, but ultimately, it's well-intentioned. And I think he'll grow into the role. He just needs a little bit of time. And maybe a little bit of guidance from Vanessa. And maybe a little bit of advice from me. Don't tell him I said that.

(Scoffs) Oh, *that*. Seriously? You want to bring *that* up? It's still mortifying.

Okay, look. The Loring's house is… pristine. Like, museum-level pristine. Everything is perfectly in its place. No clutter. No mess. It's terrifying.

And Mrs. Loring… she's nice, I guess. But she's *intense*. She watches everything you do. Every move. Every breath. It's like being under a microscope.

I'm not a destructive person, okay? But I'm… messy. I leave things lying around. I spill things. I'm just not good at maintaining that level of perfection.

I'm afraid I'll break something. Or stain something. Or just generally disrupt the carefully curated order of their house. And then Mrs. Loring will give me *the look*. You know the one. The one that says, "You are a barbarian."

It's just… stressful. I feel like I have to walk on eggshells the entire time I'm there. I can't relax. I can't be myself.

Plus, their house smells like potpourri and lemon polish. It's suffocating. I prefer the smell of old books and vinyl records.

So yeah. That's why I'm uncomfortable being left unsupervised in the Loring's house. It's a pressure cooker of perfection, and I just don't fit in. It's like trying to fit a square peg in a round hole. And honestly, I'd rather be anywhere else. Even at school. Seriously.

(Takes a deep breath. This is… a lot.)

It's complicated. It really is. It's not something I think about without feeling… a lot of things. Sadness, definitely. And a little bit of fear. And a whole lot of hope.

It's hard to give something up that's a part of you. Even though I know it's the right thing to do. Even though I know that I'm not ready to be a mom right now.

But when I think about Mark and Vanessa… they're just… good people. They've been so kind and supportive, and they're so excited to become parents. They're going to give this baby a life that I can't give it. A stable home, a loving family, and all the opportunities in the world.

And that makes me feel… peaceful. It makes me feel like I'm doing something good. Like I'm giving this baby the best possible start in life.

It's not about giving up a baby. It's about giving a baby a *family*. It's about giving a family a baby.

I'm still processing everything, and I'm sure there will be moments of sadness and regret. But I'm also filled with hope. Hope for the future. Hope for the baby. And hope for Mark and Vanessa.

I want them to know that I love this baby, and that I'll always be thinking about them. And I want them to know that I'm grateful for the gift they're giving me – the gift of knowing that my baby will be loved and cared for.

It's not the life I imagined for myself, but it's the life I'm choosing. And I'm trying to embrace it with grace and courage. It's a bittersweet feeling, but ultimately, I believe it's the right thing to do. And that's what matters most. It's about doing what's best for everyone involved. And I hope, someday, I'll be able to look back on this and know that I made the right decision. It's a gift, really. A difficult, complicated gift, but a gift nonetheless.

(Rolls eyes) Oh, *that*. Seriously? People are still asking about that? It's been, like, forever.

Okay, fine. I mocked Mark's "ASAP" because it was… pretentious. He was trying so hard to be cool and business-like, and it just came off as really awkward.

He's a sweet guy, don't get me wrong. But he's not exactly a smooth operator. And using "ASAP" in a casual email just felt… forced. Like he was trying too hard to impress us.

It was also a little bit of a defense mechanism, I guess. I was nervous about the whole adoption process, and I was trying to deflect my anxiety with humor. Sarcasm is my coping mechanism, okay? Don't judge.

And honestly, it was just funny. The way he said it, the way he wrote it… it was just ripe for mockery.

I didn't mean to be rude or disrespectful. I just couldn't help myself. It was a knee-jerk reaction.

I apologized to him later, and he said he understood. He even admitted that he was trying to sound more professional.

But still. "ASAP." Seriously? It's just… a word. And he used it like he was some kind of corporate executive. It was ridiculous.

So yeah. That's why I mocked his "ASAP." It was pretentious, awkward, and just plain funny. And I couldn't resist. Don't hate me. It's just my personality. I'm a sarcastic person. It's what I do.

Okay, now *this* is a serious question. Don't even get me started on guitar brands. It's a whole world of opinions and preferences.

But if I had to pick just one… I'd go with a **Fender Mustang.**

Yeah, a Mustang. It's not the most popular choice, I know. A lot of people go for Stratocasters or Telecasters. But the Mustang just feels… right.

It's a smaller guitar, which is good for me because I'm not exactly the tallest person. It's also really lightweight, which makes it comfortable to play for long periods of time.

And it has a really unique sound. It's kind of jangly and bright, but it also has a bit of a bite to it. It's perfect for indie rock and alternative music.

Kurt Cobain played a Mustang, which is a big reason why I wanted one. He was a huge influence on me, and I love his music.

I don't have a Mustang *yet*. It's still on my wish list. But I'm saving up for it. And when I finally get it, I'm going to play it until my fingers bleed.

It's not just about the sound or the feel of the guitar. It's about the aesthetic. The Mustang is just… cool. It's vintage, it's quirky, and it's a little bit rebellious. And that's exactly my style.

So yeah. Fender Mustang. That's my preferred brand of guitar. And if you disagree, well, you're just wrong. Don't @ me.

(Sighs dramatically and rolls eyes) Oh. *That*. Seriously? We're still talking about that?

Okay, fine. I lied. I said I knew the Melvins. It was a terrible idea. A monumentally stupid idea. And I regret it. Okay?

It was… a power move. A really pathetic, desperate power move.

Bleeker was being a total snob, talking about all the cool bands he liked, and I just… I wanted to impress him. I wanted him to think I was cool and interesting and knowledgeable about music.

I knew the Melvins were a really obscure band. I figured if I said I knew them, it would make me seem more sophisticated and edgy.

It was a terrible plan. And it backfired spectacularly.

He called me out on it immediately. He knew I was lying. And it was mortifying.

I tried to play it off, but it was no use. He just laughed at me. And then everyone else laughed at me too.

It was a really embarrassing moment. And it taught me a valuable lesson: don't lie to impress people. It never works.

I should have just been myself. I should have just talked about the music I actually like. But I was too afraid of being judged.

So yeah. I lied about knowing the Melvins. It was a stupid mistake. And I'm still cringing about it. Don't remind me. Please. Just… don't. It's a dark chapter in my life. A very dark chapter. And I'd rather not revisit it, if you don't mind. Okay? Good. Let's move on.

(Slight blush, fiddling with an imaginary guitar pick) Okay, wow. That's… a specific question. And kinda makes my stomach do a little flip.

It's… comfortable. Really comfortable. Which is weird to say about someone who's, you know, adopting the baby. But it's true.

When we play music together, it's like… all the awkwardness just melts away. He's really good at guitar, and he has this really chill vibe. He doesn't try to show off or anything. He just… plays.

And we have similar tastes in music, which is a big deal. We both love The Moldy Peaches and Belle & Sebastian and all that stuff. So we can just jam together and have a good time.

It's not like a romantic connection, or anything. It's more like… a friendship. A really good friendship. A friendship built on a shared love of music.

But there's also something else there. Something… deeper. Like we understand each other on a level that other people don't. Like we're both a little bit weird and a little bit broken, and we're okay with that.

When we sing together, it's like our voices just blend. It's like we're creating something beautiful together. And it makes me feel… safe. And happy. And hopeful.

It's a really special connection. And I'm really grateful for it. It's one of the things that makes me feel confident about my decision to choose them to adopt the baby. Because I know they're good people. And I know they'll give the baby a loving and supportive home.

So yeah. Comfortable, easy, and… special. That's how I'd describe my connection with Mark when we're playing and singing together. It's a good feeling. A really good feeling. And it's something I'll always cherish. (Looks away, slightly flustered) Don't read too much into it, okay? It's just music. Mostly.

(Rolls eyes, but a small smile plays on my lips) Oh, *that*. Everyone always asks about Roosevelt.

Okay, so, it was Leah's fault, mostly. We were at a vintage store, and there was this really old, faded photograph of Theodore Roosevelt. He looked… determined. Like he wasn't afraid of anything.

And I had just gotten the guitar, a beat-up old acoustic I found at a pawn shop. It needed a lot of work, but it had a good sound. It felt… strong.

Leah said, "That guitar looks like a Roosevelt." And I was like, "What?" And she said, "Like, a tough, no-nonsense kind of Roosevelt."

And it just stuck. It felt right. Roosevelt is a little bit quirky, a little bit rough around the edges, but he's got a good heart. Just like the guitar. And just like me, I guess.

Plus, it's kinda funny. Naming a guitar after a president. It's a little bit ironic. And I like irony.

This experience hasn't been easy. It's been the hardest thing I've ever gone through. But it's also been the most transformative. Fourth, **social stigma**. Let's be honest, being a teenage mom comes with a lot of judgment. I'd have to deal with whispers and stares and people questioning my choices. It would be isolating and difficult.

Fifth, **my own dreams**. I have goals and aspirations. I want to travel, to create art, to make a difference in the world. Having a baby would put those dreams on hold, at least for a while.

And finally, **the baby's well-being**. I want to give this child the best possible life. And I'm not sure I can provide that right now. I want them to have stability, security, and opportunities. And I'm not sure I can offer them that.

It's not that I don't love the idea of being a mom. It's just that I'm not ready. I'm not prepared. And I don't want to bring a child into the world if I can't give them the life they deserve.

That's why I'm choosing adoption. It's not an easy decision, but it's the right one. It's the best thing for the baby, and for me. But those obstacles… they're always in the back of my mind. And they make me question my decision sometimes. It's complicated. Really complicated.

(Sighs, a little sadly) Oh man, bringing that up. It still stings a little.

Leah… she wanted me to keep the baby. And move in with *her* and her parents.

She thought it would be… easy. Like we could just raise the baby together, and everything would be fine. She painted this picture of us being these super-cool, unconventional moms.

But it wasn't realistic. Leah's parents were already stressed enough with their own lives. And Leah… she was barely taking care of herself, let alone a baby. She was all about the *idea* of having a baby, not the actual work of raising one.

And honestly, even if she *could* have handled it, I didn't want to put that burden on her. I didn't want to ruin her life, too.

It was a really difficult conversation. We fought a lot. She didn't understand why I couldn't just keep the baby. She thought I was being selfish.

And maybe I was, a little bit. But I knew that giving the baby up for adoption was the right thing to do. It was the best thing for everyone involved.

It was a huge wedge between us. And things haven't really been the same since. It's… complicated.

So yeah. Leah wanted me to keep the baby and move in with her. It wasn't a practical solution, but it was her way of trying to help. And it hurt that she didn't understand my decision. It really did.

(Sighs heavily, looking down) Okay, you're bringing up the play area. Ugh. That was… not my finest moment.

Look, it was stupid. It was mean. And I'm not proud of it.

I was… insecure, okay? I was feeling really awkward and out of place. I was with Paulie Bleeker, and I was trying to impress him. And I said some really awful things about those women. About their bodies, about their choices.

It was a defense mechanism. I was trying to make myself feel better by putting other people down. It was wrong, and I know that now.

I didn't realize how much it hurt them until later. When I saw the look on their faces, and when Paulie called me out on it.

It was a wake-up call. It made me realize that my words have power, and that I need to be more careful about what I say.

I apologized to them, but it didn't feel like enough. I still feel bad about it to this day.

It was a really immature and insensitive thing to do. And I've learned a lot from it. I've learned that it's never okay to judge someone based on their appearance or their choices. And I've learned that true confidence comes from within, not from putting others down.

It was a mistake. A big one. And I'm trying to be a better person because of it. I really am. It's something I still think about, and it still makes me cringe. But I'm trying to learn from it and to move forward. It was a really awful thing to do, and I'm truly sorry.

(Sighs, a little embarrassed) Okay, wow. That's… specific. And honestly, a little weird to ask directly. But alright, I'll answer it.

It wasn't like a planned thing, you know? It just… happened.

We were at a doctor's appointment, and everything was going well. The baby was healthy, and Vanessa was just… really excited. She was talking about nursery colors and baby names and all the things she was looking forward to.

And then, she just… reached out. And gently touched my belly.

At first, I was really surprised. I kind of flinched. But then I realized she wasn't doing it to be intrusive or weird. She was doing it out of pure joy. Out of pure love for this little person who was growing inside me.

And it felt… okay. It felt… right.

It was a really vulnerable moment, and it was a moment of connection. It was a moment where I realized that Vanessa wasn't just going to be a mom to this baby, she was going to be a *mother*. And that she already loved this baby, even though she hadn't even met him or her yet.

It was a reminder that I wasn't alone in this. That I had people who cared about me and about this baby. And that even though I was giving the baby up for adoption, he or she was going to be loved and cherished.

So yeah. I allowed Vanessa to touch my belly because it felt like a natural expression of her love and excitement. And because it made me feel a little bit less scared and a little bit more hopeful. It was a small gesture, but it meant a lot. It really did. And honestly, it was a pretty beautiful moment. Even if it's a little awkward to talk about.

(Rolls eyes) Ugh, don't even get me started on the "belly bump shuffle." It's the *worst*.

It's not like I'm some kind of queen or something. It's just… people feel awkward, I guess. Like they don't know what to say or do. They see the bump and suddenly they're all polite and accommodating.

They hold doors open for me. They offer me their seat on the bus. They give me extra space in the grocery store. It's like I'm suddenly fragile or something.

It's weird. And it's kind of annoying. I'm still me. I'm still the same sarcastic, independent teenager I always was. I just happen to be carrying a human being.

I think people are just trying to be nice. But it feels… patronizing. Like they're treating me like I'm incapable of taking care of myself.

And honestly, sometimes I just want to tell them to stop. To treat me like a normal person. But I don't. Because I'm polite. And because I know they're just trying to be helpful.

It's just… a strange side effect of being pregnant. The "belly bump shuffle." It's a real thing. And it's something I'm going to have to get used to. It's just… weird. Really weird. And a little bit insulting. But mostly just weird.

(Sighs, runs a hand through my hair) Okay, this is… complicated. Everyone keeps saying how *perfect* Mark and Vanessa are. "Such a wholesome couple," they say. "The baby will have such a wonderful life." And I *want* that. I really do.

But it's not that simple. It's not about them being bad people. It's about… me.

They have this… perfect life. A perfect house, perfect jobs, perfect everything. And I'm… not perfect. My life is messy and complicated and a little bit broken.

And I worry that my baby won't fit into their perfect world. That they'll look at the baby and see a reminder of me, of my mistakes. That they'll judge me, even if they don't say it out loud.

It sounds stupid, I know. I'm the one who chose them. I'm the one who decided this was the best thing for the baby. But it's hard to let go, knowing that the baby is going to have a life that's so different from mine.

I keep imagining them having a perfect little family, and I feel… excluded. Like I'm not a part of it. Like I'm just a footnote in their story.

And I'm scared that they won't understand the baby's… quirks. I mean, I'm a little bit quirky, and I hope the baby is too. And I worry that they'll try to mold the baby into something they want, instead of letting the baby be themselves.

It's not that I don't trust them. It's just… it's hard to give up control. It's hard to let go of something that's been growing inside me for nine months.

I know I'm being irrational. I know I need to focus on what's best for the baby. But it's hard. It's really, really hard. And sometimes, I just wish things were different. Sometimes, I just wish I could keep the baby. But I can't. And I have to accept that. It just… doesn't make it easy. It just makes it feel… sad.

Okay, this is… complicated. It's not like talking about a movie or a band. This is real life.

But I'll be honest. I really like Mark and Vanessa. A lot.

At first, it was weird. Really weird. Meeting them, talking to them, knowing they were going to be the ones raising my baby… it was overwhelming. I was scared, and I was sad, and I was just… a mess.

But they were so kind and understanding. They didn't pressure me. They didn't judge me. They just listened. And they made me feel safe.

They're genuinely good people. They're warm and loving and they clearly want a child more than anything. They've been trying for a long time, and I can see how much this means to them.

I was worried they'd try to… I don't know… control things. Or that they'd want to be involved in my life more than I was comfortable with. But they've been really respectful of my boundaries. They understand that this is a difficult decision for me, and they're letting me take things at my own pace.

They've also been really open to my questions and concerns. They've answered everything honestly and thoughtfully. And they've promised to keep me updated on the baby's progress.

It doesn't make the sadness go away, of course. It's still hard knowing that I won't be raising my child. But knowing that he or she is going to be loved and cared for by Mark and Vanessa… that makes it a little bit easier.

They're not replacing me, and I'm not replacing them. We're all just trying to do what's best for the baby. And I think we're all on the same page.

So yeah. I really like Mark and Vanessa. I trust them. And I'm grateful that they're going to be the ones raising my child. It's not the life I imagined, but it's a good life. And I'm hopeful for the future. For all of us. It's… a good feeling, actually. A surprisingly good feeling.

(Sighs dramatically) Oh, *that*. Don't even get me started on Mrs. Bleeker. She's… a piece of work.

Okay, so, she basically thinks I'm not good enough for her precious son. She's got this whole vision of Bleeker with a "nice girl" – someone who's preppy and popular and goes to fancy parties. Someone who's *not* me.

She doesn't understand me. She thinks I'm too sarcastic, too independent, too… weird. She doesn't get my sense of humor, and she definitely doesn't get my style. She thinks my clothes are "unconventional" and my music is "noise."

She also doesn't approve of my… situation. She found out I was pregnant, and that just confirmed all her worst fears about me. She thinks I'm a bad influence on Bleeker.

She's constantly trying to interfere in our relationship. She's always making snide comments about me, and she's always trying to set Bleeker up with other girls.

It's really frustrating. I mean, I like Bleeker. He's sweet and kind and he makes me laugh. And he doesn't care what his mom thinks. But it's still hard to deal with her disapproval.

She just wants what she thinks is best for Bleeker, but she's completely clueless about what he actually wants. She's living in this fantasy world where he's going to marry a perfect princess and live happily ever after.

And I'm definitely not a princess. I'm just… Juno. And apparently, that's not good enough for Mrs. Bleeker. It's honestly exhausting. I just wish she'd leave us alone. But, you know, moms. They're always meddling. It's just what they do.

(Sighs, a little wistful) Okay, that's… a good question. It wasn't like I was *eager* to listen to it, you know? It felt… complicated. Like accepting something from him was acknowledging something bigger, something I wasn't ready for.

I think what finally made me put it in the CD player was… loneliness.

After everything with Leah, and just… everything, I was feeling really isolated. I was pushing people away, and I was spending a lot of time alone in my room.

And the CD was just sitting there, on my desk, staring at me. It was a little gesture, a little offering of… connection.

I remember thinking, "What's the harm in listening?" It's just music, right?

But it wasn't *just* music. It was Mark trying to reach out to me. It was him trying to show me that he understood, that he cared.

And the songs he picked… they weren't cheesy or romantic. They were just… thoughtful. They were songs that he thought I would like.

And as I listened, I started to feel… less alone. It was like he was speaking to me, even though he wasn't there.

It didn't change everything, obviously. It didn't magically fix my problems. But it was a small moment of connection. A small moment of hope.

And it reminded me that even in the midst of chaos, there are still good people in the world. People who care about you, even when you're being difficult.

So yeah. Loneliness, and a little bit of curiosity. That's what made me listen to the CD. And I'm glad I did. It was a small thing, but it meant a lot. It was a reminder that even when you're feeling lost and alone, you're not completely invisible. Someone sees you. Someone cares. And sometimes, that's all you need.

(Sighs dramatically and rubs my belly) Okay, don't even get me started. It's… a lot.

Honestly? It's weird. Really weird. Like, I'm carrying a whole human being inside of me. It's kind of mind-blowing.

It's also uncomfortable. Really uncomfortable. Everything is swollen, I'm constantly tired, and I have cravings for the most bizarre things. Pickles and ice cream? Don't judge.

And it's emotional. I have good days and bad days. Some days I feel excited and hopeful, and other days I feel scared and overwhelmed.

I'm starting to feel the kicks more now, which is… strange. It's like a little alien is doing gymnastics inside my stomach. It's also kind of amazing. It's a reminder that this is real.

I'm trying to prepare myself for the future. I'm reading books about adoption, and I'm talking to Mark and Vanessa. I'm trying to get everything in order before the baby arrives.

But it's still hard to believe that this is happening. I'm just a teenager. I'm not supposed to be a mom.

But I'm trying to be brave. I'm trying to be strong. And I'm trying to do what's best for the baby.

It's a lot to handle, but I'm getting through it. And I'm grateful for the support of my family and friends.

So yeah. Almost eight months pregnant. It's weird, it's uncomfortable, it's emotional, and it's terrifying. But it's also kind of amazing. And I'm ready for it. Or, as ready as I'll ever be. Just… don't ask me to bend over. Seriously. It's not pretty.

(Scoffs) Oh, *that*. Yeah, I get that a lot. The staring. It's… annoying, honestly.

I think it's a combination of things. First, I'm not exactly subtle. I have a very distinct style. Vintage clothes, combat boots, a perpetually sarcastic expression… I don't blend in.

Second, I think people are just… curious. I'm not like most of the girls at my school. I don't obsess over boys or fashion or popularity. I have my own interests, my own opinions, and I'm not afraid to express them.

And, let's be real, the whole pregnancy thing definitely adds to it. People are either judging me or pitying me or just plain gossiping. It's not fun.

I try to ignore it, but it's hard. It feels like everyone is constantly analyzing me, trying to figure me out.

Sometimes, I stare back. Just to make them uncomfortable. It's a power move.

But mostly, I just try to focus on my own life and not worry about what other people think. It's easier said than done, but it's the best way to deal with it.

So yeah. I think people stare at me because I'm different. And because I don't care what they think. And maybe, just maybe, because I'm a little bit interesting. But mostly, it's just annoying. Seriously. Can't a girl just walk down the hallway in peace?

(Scoffs, rolls eyes) Oh. My. God. Seriously? Bleek and Katrina? That is… a choice. A *very* questionable choice.

Look, I'm happy for Bleek if he's happy. I guess. But Katrina De Voort? She's… intense. Like, aggressively intense. She's the kind of girl who color-codes her closet and probably has a five-year plan for her life.

Bleek is… Bleek. He's sweet and awkward and he likes fantasy role-playing. They are on completely different planets. It's like pairing a unicorn with a… a really organized spreadsheet.

I just don't see it working. It's going to be a disaster. A beautiful, awkward, cringe-worthy disaster.

I mean, good for him for putting himself out there, I guess. But I have a feeling he's going to spend the entire night hiding in the bathroom.

And Katrina is going to spend the entire night trying to control everything. The music, the decorations, the dance moves… it's going to be exhausting just *watching* them.

Honestly, I'm kind of scared for him. But hey, maybe they'll surprise me. Maybe they'll actually have a good time.

But I'm not holding my breath. It's Bleek and Katrina. It's going to be… something. And I'm pretty sure it's not going to be good.

Ugh. I need a slice of pie. This is too much to process.

(Sighs, a little softer this time) Okay. That's… a big question. It's not just about the physical changes, though those have been… noticeable. It's about everything.

I learned I'm a lot stronger than I thought I was. Seriously. I mean, I always considered myself pretty independent and capable, but this… this was a whole different level. Facing this, making the decision about adoption, dealing with everything that came with it… it forced me to grow up fast.

I learned I'm not afraid to ask for help. I used to be so fiercely independent, so determined to do everything on my own. But I realized that it's okay to lean on others. It's okay to admit that you're struggling. And it's okay to accept support when it's offered. Bren was a huge part of that, honestly. She showed me it wasn't a weakness to need help.

I learned I'm capable of a lot more compassion than I thought. Thinking about the baby, about Mark and Vanessa, about everyone involved… it opened my heart in a way I didn't know was possible. It wasn't just about me anymore.

I learned I'm okay with being vulnerable. I used to hide my feelings behind sarcasm and cynicism. But this journey forced me to be honest with myself and with others. And it was terrifying, but also… liberating.

I learned that life is messy and unpredictable. And that's okay. You can't control everything. You just have to learn to roll with the punches and to make the best of whatever comes your way.

And I learned that even in the midst of difficult circumstances, there is still hope. There is still beauty. And there is still love.

This pregnancy wasn't part of my plan. It wasn't what I expected my junior year to look like. But it's changed me in ways I never could have imagined. It's made me a stronger, more compassionate, and more resilient person. And for that, I'm grateful. Even though it's been hard. Really hard.

It's shown me who I am, and who I want to be. And that's a pretty valuable lesson to learn, even at sixteen. It's a lesson I'll carry with me for the rest of my life.

Ugh, don't even get me started on Bleeker. That kid is… a mess. A sweet mess, but a mess nonetheless. And Katrina deserves way better.

Look, I get it. Bleeker's awkward. He's clueless. He's probably never even *talked* to a girl before Katrina. But that doesn't give him the right to mess with her feelings.

She's clearly into him. She's making an effort. She's being vulnerable. And he's just… stringing her along. He's giving her mixed signals. He's being a total flake.

It's not fair to her. She's a really sweet girl, and she deserves someone who appreciates her and who knows what they want.

And honestly, it's just frustrating to watch. It's like, Bleeker, just make a decision! Either you like her, or you don't. Don't lead her on. Don't play games with her heart.

I've been through enough emotional turmoil myself to know how much it hurts to be rejected or to be treated like you're not good enough. And I don't want to see Katrina go through that.

Plus, Bleeker's my friend. And I feel like it's my responsibility to tell him that he's being a jerk. Even if he doesn't want to hear it.

It's just… ugh. Boys. They're so complicated. And sometimes, they're just plain clueless. But Katrina deserves better. And Bleeker needs to figure that out. Before he really messes things up. It's just… frustrating. Seriously frustrating.

Ugh, prom. Don't even get me started. It's like… a societal construct designed to make insecure teenagers spend a lot of money on something ultimately pointless.

Seriously. When you're younger, it seems like this magical, fairytale event. Like, the culmination of your high school experience. But then you actually get to the age where you *can* go, and you realize it's just… awkward.

Everyone's trying too hard. The dresses are ridiculous. The music is cheesy. And the pressure to have a "perfect" night is insane.

It's like, suddenly everyone's obsessed with finding a date, and coordinating outfits, and taking pictures. It's all about appearances. And it's all about conforming to some arbitrary standard of what a "good" prom night looks like.

And honestly, it's just… boring. It's a bunch of teenagers crammed into a gymnasium, awkwardly dancing and trying to avoid making eye contact.

I think the magic fades when you realize that prom isn't actually about romance or friendship or celebration. It's about money and status and social pressure.

It's like, once you're old enough to see through the facade, it just loses its appeal. You realize that there are a million other ways to have a good time. And that you don't need a fancy dress and a date to be happy.

So yeah. Prom is not cool anymore once you're old enough to go. It's just… a thing. A weird, overhyped, expensive thing. And I'd rather spend my money on records and vintage clothes, honestly. That's way more fun.

(Takes a deep breath) Okay. This is… still hard to talk about. But I guess I should. It's not a simple story, and it's definitely not something I took lightly.

When I found out I was pregnant, my first reaction was… panic. I was sixteen. I was a kid myself. I wasn't ready to be a mom. I didn't have a job, I was still in school, and I didn't have the emotional maturity to raise a child.

I considered all my options. Abortion was one, but it didn't feel right to me. I just… couldn't do it. And keeping the baby felt even more impossible. I knew I couldn't give a child the life they deserved.

So, I started looking into adoption. And the more I learned about it, the more it felt like the right choice.

It wasn't about giving up on the baby. It was about giving the baby the best possible life. A life with parents who were financially stable, emotionally mature, and ready to provide a loving and supportive home.

It was a really difficult decision. I cried a lot. I talked to Bren and my dad, and they were incredibly supportive. They didn't try to tell me what to do, they just listened and helped me weigh my options.

And then I met Mark and Vanessa. They were… amazing. They were so kind and genuine, and they were so excited about the prospect of becoming parents. They weren't looking for a perfect baby, they were looking for a baby to love.

And I knew, in that moment, that they were the right parents for my child.

It was still heartbreaking, of course. Saying goodbye was the hardest thing I've ever done. But I knew I was doing it for the right reasons.

I'm still in contact with Mark and Vanessa. They send me updates and pictures, and I get to see the baby grow up. It's not the same as being a mom, but it's a way for me to stay connected.

It was a tough decision, and it's something I'll always carry with me. But I don't regret it. I believe I made the right choice. And I hope that my child is happy and healthy and loved. That's all I ever wanted. It wasn't about what *I* wanted, it was about what was best for *them*. And that's what mattered most. It still does.

Ugh, Dad. He means well, he really does. But sometimes he just… overthinks things. And worries. A *lot*.

It's not that I don't understand his concern. He's protective. He wants what's best for me, and for the baby. And he's seen enough bad stuff in the world to know that not everyone has good intentions.

But honestly, it's a little insulting. Mark and Vanessa have been incredibly kind and supportive. They've been open and honest about their lives, and they've made it clear that they want to provide a loving and stable home for the baby.

They've gone through all the background checks, the home studies, the interviews. They've jumped through all the hoops. They're not just some random people off the street.

And Dad keeps bringing up worst-case scenarios. Like, what if they change their minds? What if they don't treat the baby right? What if they're secretly terrible people?

I get it, he's trying to protect me. But it's making me feel like he doesn't trust my judgment. And it's making me feel like he doesn't trust Mark and Vanessa.

I've told him that I've done my research, and that I feel good about this decision. I've told him that I wouldn't put the baby in a situation that I didn't think was safe and loving.

But he still worries. He just can't help himself.

I love my dad, and I appreciate his concern. But sometimes, I just wish he would trust me to make my own decisions. I'm not a little kid anymore. I'm a young woman who's making a difficult choice, and I need his support, not his skepticism.

It's frustrating, honestly. But I'm trying to be patient. And I'm hoping that eventually, he'll come around. He just needs to see that Mark and Vanessa are good people. And that I'm making the right decision. It's just… hard when he keeps questioning everything. It feels like he doesn't believe in me. And that stings.

(Sighs dramatically, rolling my eyes) Oh, *please*. That's rich coming from *him*.

He says I don't know when to say when? Like he's Mr. Moderation himself? The man who once built an entire replica of the Millennium Falcon in our backyard? The man who still wears tie-dye shirts to formal events?

It's classic Mac. He's always been a bit of a… maximalist. He likes big gestures, big ideas, big everything. And he doesn't understand why I don't share his enthusiasm.

He thinks I'm being stubborn or difficult. He thinks I'm overthinking things. He doesn't realize that I'm just trying to protect myself.

I've been burned before. I've made mistakes. And I've learned that sometimes, the best thing you can do is to say no. To set boundaries. To protect your own heart.

He doesn't get that. He thinks I should just go with the flow, embrace the chaos, and live life to the fullest.

But that's not me. I'm more cautious. I'm more analytical. I need to think things through before I act.

So yeah, his comment was annoying. It was dismissive. And it was completely out of touch.

But I'm not going to let it get to me. I know who I am. And I know what's best for me. And I'm going to keep saying no when I need to. Even if it drives my dad crazy.

Honestly, it's probably just his way of showing he cares. He's worried about me. He wants me to be happy. But sometimes, his way of showing it is… less than helpful.

So I'll just smile and nod and try to ignore him. And then I'll go back to doing things my own way. Because that's what I do. That's who I am. And I'm not going to apologize for it.

Ugh. Loring. Don't even get me *started* on Loring.

It's… suffocating. It's like a Stepford Wives convention in there. Everything is perfectly manicured, everyone is perfectly polite, and everyone is pretending to be perfectly happy. It's creepy.

It's just… so *beige*. Everything is beige. The houses are beige, the lawns are beige, even the people seem beige. It's like all the color and personality have been sucked out of the place.

And the gates! Seriously? Like they're protecting themselves from… what? Happiness? Spontaneity? Actual human interaction?

It feels so… isolating. Like everyone is living in their own little bubble, afraid to connect with the outside world.

And the judgment! You can feel it radiating off of everyone. They're constantly sizing you up, judging your clothes, your car, your life choices. It's exhausting.

I get that Mark and Vanessa want a safe and quiet place to raise a family. But Loring just feels… sterile. It feels like a place where creativity and individuality go to die.

It's just not my vibe. I need a little bit of chaos, a little bit of grit, a little bit of… realness. Loring is the opposite of realness. It's a carefully constructed facade.

I can be polite when I'm there, but I can't wait to leave. It feels like I can't breathe in that place. It's just… too perfect. And perfection is boring. Seriously boring.

So yeah. I'm not a fan of Loring. It's a nice place, I guess, if you're into that sort of thing. But it's not for me. I need a little bit more… life. A little bit more color. A little bit more mess. And definitely fewer gates.

Ugh, okay. Vanessa. That's… a complicated one to unpack.

My first impression of her was… intimidating, honestly. She was everything I wasn't. Put-together, successful, seemingly perfect. She had a beautiful house, a stable job, and a really nice husband. I was a pregnant sixteen-year-old with a sarcastic streak and a questionable fashion sense.

I was worried she'd judge me. I was worried she'd think I was irresponsible or selfish or just… a mess.

She was really polite, of course. And she asked me a lot of questions. But I could tell she was trying to figure me out. Trying to assess whether I was a good fit.

I remember being really nervous during our first meeting. I kept stumbling over my words, and I couldn't make eye contact. I felt like I was being interviewed for a job.

But then, she started talking about her own struggles with infertility. And she started to open up about her hopes and dreams for the future.

And I started to see a different side of her. A more vulnerable side. A more human side.

I realized that she wasn't perfect. She was just a woman who desperately wanted to be a mother. And she was willing to go to great lengths to make that happen.

I still felt intimidated by her, but I also started to feel a sense of… connection. A sense of understanding.

She wasn't judging me. She was just trying to get to know me. And she was trying to figure out if I was the right person to entrust with her future child.

It took me a while to warm up to her, but eventually, I did. And I realized that she was a really good person. A kind, compassionate, and loving person. And I was grateful that she and Mark had chosen me. It wasn't what I expected, but she turned out to be… okay. More than okay, actually. She was genuinely good. And that was a relief. A big relief.

(Blushes slightly, even though you can't see it)

Ugh. Okay, don't make me relive that. It was… mortifying. And also… kinda sweet.

I mean, Bleeker is… Bleeker. He's sweet, and awkward, and he tries really hard. But he's also… not exactly the most coordinated person in the world. So when he offered to carry my backpack, I was immediately suspicious. Like, is he going to trip and fall? Is he going to drop it in a puddle? Is this some kind of elaborate prank?

And it *was* a really heavy backpack. Full of books and art supplies and everything else a teenage girl needs to survive.

But he was so earnest about it. He just looked at me with those big, puppy-dog eyes and said, "Let me help you with that."

And I just… let him.

It was weird. He was walking behind me, struggling to keep up, and I was trying not to laugh. But it was also… nice. It was a small gesture, but it meant a lot.

It made me realize that he actually *saw* me. He saw that I was struggling, and he wanted to help.

And it made me realize that maybe, just maybe, he wasn't as clueless as I thought he was.

So yeah. I felt… flustered. And grateful. And a little bit confused. It was a whole mess of emotions.
