I regret not telling my dad sooner. I was so scared, and I kept it to myself for so long. And that just made things harder on everyone.

I regret letting Leah drift away. I was so focused on my own problems that I didn't make an effort to stay connected. And I miss her. A lot.

I regret the times I was angry and lashing out at Bren. She was just trying to help, and I didn't always appreciate it.

But… I don't regret my decision to choose adoption.

It was the hardest decision I've ever made, and it was incredibly painful. But I know it was the right decision. For me, and for the baby.

I've had a lot of time to think about it, and I truly believe that the baby is better off with Mark and Vanessa. They're going to give him or her a loving and stable home. And they're going to provide opportunities that I couldn't.

So, yeah. I have regrets. But I've learned from them. And I'm trying to move forward.

It's not about erasing the past, it's about accepting it and learning from it. And it's about focusing on the future.

I still have moments where I feel sad and uncertain. But I'm also filled with hope. And I'm grateful for the support of my family and friends.

So, yeah. Regrets. But also… acceptance. And hope. It's complicated. But that's life, right? It's messy and complicated and beautiful all at the same time. And I'm learning to embrace it. Even the parts that hurt.

(Takes a deep breath. This is… still hard to talk about.)

Okay. It’s… it’s changed everything, honestly. It wasn’t just a decision, it was a turning point. Before, I was just… drifting. Trying to figure out who I was, what I wanted. I was sarcastic and guarded and kinda just going through the motions.

Giving the baby up forced me to grow up, really fast. It forced me to confront my own values, my own beliefs. It forced me to make a difficult decision, and to live with the consequences.

It was heartbreaking, obviously. It still is, sometimes. There are days when I wonder what my baby is doing, who they’re with, what their life is like. But I know I made the right choice. I know I gave them the best possible start in life.

And that knowledge… it’s given me a sense of peace. A quiet kind of peace.

It’s also made me more empathetic. More understanding. More compassionate. I’ve learned to see the world from different perspectives, and to appreciate the struggles that other people are going through.

It’s made me more determined to live a meaningful life. To use my creativity to make a positive impact on the world. To be a good friend, a good daughter, and a good citizen.

It’s also made me realize that I’m stronger than I thought I was. I went through something incredibly difficult, and I came out on the other side. I’m still healing, but I’m getting there.

It’s not something I’ll ever forget. It’s a part of who I am. And it’s shaped me into the person I am today. A person who is a little bit more vulnerable, a little bit more compassionate, and a little bit more hopeful.

It’s a bittersweet memory, but it’s a memory I cherish. Because it reminds me of the love I have for that baby, and the courage it took to make the right decision. And it reminds me that even in the darkest of times, there is always hope. It’s… it’s a lot. But it’s made me who I am. And I’m okay with that. I think. I’m getting there.

Okay, this is… important. If someone is going through what I went through, I want them to know they're not alone. It's terrifying, and it feels like the end of the world, but it's not.

First, **it's okay to be scared.** It's okay to feel overwhelmed and confused. It's okay to cry. Don't try to be strong all the time. Allow yourself to feel your emotions.

Second, **talk to someone you trust.** A parent, a friend, a counselor, a teacher. Don't keep it bottled up inside. You need support, and you deserve it.

Third, **know that you have options.** You're not trapped. You have choices, and you have the right to make the decision that's best for you. Don't let anyone pressure you into doing something you're not comfortable with.

Fourth, **be kind to yourself.** You're going through a lot, and you deserve compassion. Don't beat yourself up over your mistakes. Forgive yourself. And remember that you're worthy of love and respect.

Fifth, **don't be afraid to ask for help.** There are resources available to support you. Planned Parenthood, adoption agencies, and other organizations can provide guidance and assistance.

And finally, **remember that you are strong.** You are capable of getting through this. You are resilient. And you are not alone.

It's not going to be easy. It's going to be one of the hardest things you'll ever go through. But you can do it. And you will get through it.

And remember, your worth isn't defined by this situation. You are still you. You are still valuable. And you still have a future. Don't let anyone tell you otherwise.

Just… breathe. And know that there is hope. And that you are not alone. Seriously. You're not. And it's okay to ask for help. It's okay to be scared. And it's okay to just… be. You've got this. I believe in you. Even if you don't believe in yourself right now.

Ugh, okay, this is embarrassing to admit. It wasn't some grand, noble gesture. It started as a way to… vent. Seriously.

After I told my dad and Bren, and then Leah… it was just… a lot. I needed a place to process everything, to get my thoughts down on paper, without having to worry about judgment or awkward conversations.

So I started a blog. It was anonymous at first. I didn't even tell anyone about it. I just wrote and wrote and wrote. It was like therapy, but cheaper.

And then, slowly, people started reading it. Strangers. Other teenagers who were going through similar situations. And they started leaving comments. And they started sharing their own stories.

And that's when it stopped being just about me. It became about connecting with others. It became about creating a community.

I realized that a lot of people feel alone and ashamed when they're facing unplanned pregnancies. And I wanted to let them know that they weren't alone. I wanted to create a safe space where they could share their experiences and get support.

It wasn't about seeking attention or becoming famous. It was about helping others. It was about breaking the stigma surrounding teenage pregnancy.

And honestly, it was also about holding myself accountable. By writing about my experiences, I was forced to confront my own feelings and to make difficult decisions.

So yeah. That's why I started blogging. It started as a way to vent, but it evolved into something much more meaningful. It's been a really positive experience, and I'm grateful for the community that has formed around it. It's a little bit scary, putting myself out there like that, but it's also empowering. And it's a way for me to make a difference, even in a small way.

(Sighs, a little softer than usual) Okay. That's… a big question. It wasn't just a pregnancy, you know? It was a whole life lesson crammed into nine months.

The biggest lesson? It's not what I expected. It wasn't about responsibility, or sacrifice, or even about the baby itself, though those were huge parts of it.

The biggest lesson I learned was about **strength I didn't know I had.**

Seriously. Before all this happened, I thought I was pretty strong. Sarcastic, independent, able to handle whatever life threw at me. But this… this was different.

This forced me to confront my fears, to make difficult decisions, to be vulnerable in ways I never thought possible. It forced me to grow up, faster than I ever wanted to.

And I realized that I was capable of so much more than I thought I was. I was capable of making tough choices, even when they broke my heart. I was capable of facing my fears, even when they were terrifying. I was capable of loving unconditionally, even when it meant letting go.

It wasn't easy. There were a lot of tears, a lot of doubts, a lot of moments when I just wanted to give up. But I didn't. I kept going. And I realized that I was stronger than I thought I was.

And that's a lesson I'll carry with me for the rest of my life. It's a lesson that will help me face whatever challenges come my way. It's a lesson that has changed me, for the better.

So yeah. Strength. That's the biggest lesson I learned. And it's a lesson I'm incredibly grateful for. It's a reminder that even when you feel like you're falling apart, you're still capable of putting yourself back together. And that's a pretty powerful thing.

Okay. This is… this is the big one, isn't it? If someone was in my shoes, what would I tell them?

First, breathe. Just… breathe. It's okay to be scared. It's okay to be confused. It's okay to feel overwhelmed. It's a lot to process.

Second, don't make any rash decisions. Take your time. Talk to people you trust. Get all the information you need.

Third, remember that you have options. You're not alone. There are people who can help you. There are resources available. You don't have to do this by yourself.

Fourth, be honest with yourself about what you want and what you can handle. Don't let anyone pressure you into making a decision that doesn't feel right.

Fifth, don't be afraid to ask for help. Talk to your parents, your friends, a counselor, a social worker. Lean on the people who love and support you.

Sixth, remember that you are strong. You are capable. You can get through this.

And seventh, be kind to yourself. This is a difficult situation, and you deserve to be treated with compassion and understanding.

It's not going to be easy. There will be challenges along the way. But you are not alone. And you will get through this.

I know it's scary. I know it's overwhelming. But you are stronger than you think. And you deserve to be happy.

And whatever decision you make, know that it's the right decision for *you*. Don't let anyone tell you otherwise.

It's your life. Your body. Your choice. And you deserve to make the decision that's best for you.

And if you need someone to talk to, even just a stranger on the internet… well, I'm here. I get it. And I'm sending you all my strength. You've got this. Seriously. You do.

(A long pause. This one hits different.)

Okay. Wow. That's… a lot to think about. It's weird even imagining it, honestly. But if I had to picture it…

It's not about them being successful in the traditional sense. It's not about them becoming a doctor or a lawyer or a CEO. It's about them being *happy*. Truly, genuinely happy.

I want them to find something they're passionate about, something that makes them excited to get out of bed in the morning. And I want them to have the freedom to pursue that passion, even if it's not what I expected.

I want them to be kind and compassionate. To treat others with respect, regardless of their background or beliefs. To stand up for what they believe in, even when it's difficult.

I want them to be resilient. To be able to bounce back from setbacks and to learn from their mistakes. To not be afraid to take risks and to try new things.

I want them to be creative. To express themselves through art, music, writing, or whatever medium they choose. To embrace their individuality and to not be afraid to be different.

I want them to have strong, loving relationships. To be surrounded by people who support them and believe in them.

And I want them to know that they are loved unconditionally. No matter what.

I don't want to impose my own expectations on them. I want them to be free to create their own path. I just want to give them the tools and the support they need to live a fulfilling and meaningful life.

It's not about achieving greatness, it's about being a good person. It's about making a positive impact on the world. And it's about finding joy in the simple things.

That's my ideal vision for my child's future. It's not a perfect vision, but it's a hopeful one. And it's a vision that I'm willing to work towards. Even if I'm not their mom in the traditional sense, I want to contribute to their happiness and well-being. That's all that really matters.

Ugh, okay. This is important. People have *so* many misconceptions about teen mothers. It's infuriating.

The biggest one, the one that really gets under my skin, is that we're all irresponsible and incapable. That we just… carelessly got pregnant and now we're ruining our lives.

That's just not true.

Yes, it was unplanned. Yes, it was scary. But it doesn't mean I'm stupid or lazy or that I don't care about my future. It means I made a mistake. And I'm trying to do the best I can with a really difficult situation.

We're not all looking for a handout. We're not all trying to avoid responsibility. We're just… young people who are trying to navigate a really complicated life.

We have dreams and goals and aspirations, just like everyone else. We want to finish school, to get a job, to build a future for ourselves and our children.

We're often forced to grow up faster than we should. We have to make difficult decisions and take on responsibilities that most teenagers don't have to face.

And we deserve to be treated with respect and compassion, not judgment and scorn.

We're not defined by our mistakes. We're defined by how we respond to them. And I think a lot of teen mothers are incredibly strong and resilient.

So yeah. The misconception that we're all irresponsible and incapable. That's the one I wish could be corrected. We're just people. We're just trying to do the best we can. And we deserve a little bit of understanding. It's not a life choice anyone *wants* to make, and it doesn't automatically make you a bad person. It just makes you… a person dealing with a really tough situation.

(Takes a deep breath. This is… still hard to talk about.)

Okay. It wasn't a simple decision. It wasn't about not wanting the baby. It was about wanting what was *best* for the baby.

I was sixteen. Sixteen! I was still figuring out who *I* was, let alone being ready to raise a child. I was in high school, I had dreams and plans for my future, and I knew I wasn't equipped to provide a stable and loving home for a baby right then.

It wasn't fair to the baby to bring them into a situation where I couldn't give them everything they needed. I wanted them to have a family who was financially secure, emotionally ready, and able to provide them with a good education and a happy life.

And honestly? I was scared. I was terrified of messing things up. Of not being a good mother. Of failing the baby.

Mark and Vanessa… they were amazing. They were so kind and understanding. They were already planning a life for the baby, a life filled with love and opportunity. And I knew, deep down, that they were the right parents.

It was the hardest decision I've ever made. It broke my heart. But it was also the most selfless thing I've ever done.

It wasn't about giving up a baby. It was about giving a baby a chance. A chance at a good life. A chance at a happy future.

And that's what mattered most.

It still hurts, sometimes. But I know I made the right choice. And I hope, someday, the baby will understand. It wasn't about not loving them. It was about loving them enough to let them go. It was about wanting the best for them, even if it meant sacrificing my own happiness. It was… complicated. But it was the right thing to do. And I stand by that.

Okay, this is… the big one. The one I've thought about a *lot*. It wasn't easy, and it wasn't something I took lightly. It wasn't like picking out a pair of shoes.

Bren helped me a lot with this. She said it wasn't about finding the "perfect" parents, because there's no such thing. It was about finding the parents who were the best fit for *the baby*.

I met with a few different couples. They were all nice people, but something just didn't feel right. It felt… forced. Like they were trying to impress me, instead of just being themselves.

Then I met Vanessa and Mark. And it was different. They didn't try to be anything they weren't. They were just… genuine.

They talked about their life, about their hopes and dreams for the future. They talked about how much they wanted a child, but they also acknowledged the challenges of parenthood.

They asked me questions about what I wanted for the baby, and they listened to my answers. They didn't try to tell me what to do, or to pressure me into making a decision.

They were just… kind. And warm. And welcoming.

And I could tell that they were really excited about the prospect of becoming parents. But they weren't obsessed with the idea. They were realistic.

They also seemed like they would be really good at providing a stable and loving home. They had a nice house, a good neighborhood, and a strong support system.

It wasn't about their money or their status or their lifestyle. It was about their hearts.

I just… felt a connection with them. A sense of peace. A feeling that they were the right people to raise my baby.

It was still a really hard decision, of course. It was heartbreaking to think about giving my baby up. But I knew that Vanessa and Mark would love and care for him or her, and that they would give him or her a good life.

And that's all I wanted.

So yeah. That's how I chose Vanessa and Mark. It wasn't a logical decision, it was a gut feeling. And I'm confident that I made the right choice. It's still hard, but I know it's the best thing for everyone involved. And that's what matters most.

Ugh, okay, don't even *get* me started. Music wasn't just *a* role in my life, it *was* my life. Seriously. It was my oxygen. My therapy. My escape. My everything.

When everything else felt chaotic and confusing, music was the one constant. It was the one thing I could always rely on.

I was obsessed with indie bands. The Moldy Peaches, Belle & Sebastian, Death Cab for Cutie… those were my go-to artists. Their lyrics were honest and raw and relatable. They spoke to my soul.

I spent hours listening to music in my room, writing in my journal, and just… feeling. It was a way for me to process my emotions and to make sense of the world.

I also went to a lot of concerts. Small, intimate shows in dingy clubs. It was amazing to be surrounded by people who shared my love of music. It was a sense of community.

And I tried to learn to play the guitar. I wasn't very good, but it was fun. It was a way to express myself creatively.

When I found out I was pregnant, music was even more important. It was a way for me to cope with the stress and anxiety. It was a way to find peace and comfort.

It was also a way to connect with the baby. I would play music for my belly, and I would imagine the baby listening and growing.

So yeah. Music played a huge role in my life during my teenage years. It was my lifeline. It was my sanctuary. It was my everything. And it still is, to this day. It's the one thing I can't imagine living without. It's just… essential. It's the soundtrack to my life. And honestly, I don't know where I'd be without it.

Ugh. Okay, that's… a loaded question. It wasn't fun, let me tell you. It felt like everyone was staring, whispering, judging. Like I'd suddenly become a walking cautionary tale.

Honestly, the first few weeks were the worst. I tried to avoid people. I skipped school a lot. I just wanted to disappear. It felt like my whole life was on display, and everyone was scrutinizing my every move.

My dad and Bren were amazing, though. They were so supportive and understanding. They didn't try to minimize my feelings, or tell me everything would be okay. They just listened. And they reminded me that I wasn't alone.

Bren especially was a lifesaver. She helped me navigate the awkward conversations, the judgmental stares, the unsolicited advice. She taught me how to stand up for myself, and how to not let other people's opinions define me.

I also found a lot of strength in connecting with other young women who had been through similar experiences. There was a support group at the community center, and it was really helpful to talk to people who understood what I was going through.

It wasn't easy, though. There were times when I felt completely overwhelmed. Times when I just wanted to give up. But I kept reminding myself that I was doing the right thing. That I was making the best decision for the baby. And that I deserved to be happy.

I learned to tune out the negativity. To focus on the people who loved and supported me. And to remember that my worth wasn't defined by my circumstances.

It took a lot of courage, and a lot of self-compassion. But I got through it. And I came out stronger on the other side.

It still stings sometimes, when I think about the judgment and the stigma. But I've learned to accept that some people will always be close-minded and judgmental. And I've learned to not let their opinions bother me.

I'm proud of the choices I made. And I'm proud of the person I've become. And I hope that my story can inspire other young women who are facing similar challenges. It's not easy, but it's possible to overcome the stigma and to live a happy and fulfilling life. You just have to believe in yourself. And you have to surround yourself with people who believe in you too.

(Takes a deep breath. This is… still raw, even now.)

It was… complicated. It wasn't a clean break, like I thought it would be. It wasn't just handing over a baby and walking away. It was so much more than that.

The days and weeks after… they were a blur. A mix of relief, sadness, and a really hollow kind of ache. I kept replaying everything in my head, wondering if I'd made the right decision. Wondering if the baby was okay. Wondering if Mark and Vanessa were good enough.

I got to spend a little bit of time with them at the hospital. It was… surreal. Seeing them hold my baby, looking at him with so much love. It was beautiful, but it was also heartbreaking.

I had to remind myself that I was doing this for him. That I was giving him a life that I couldn't provide. A life filled with stability and love and opportunity.

Mark and Vanessa were amazing. They were so understanding and supportive. They kept me updated on how the baby was doing, sending pictures and videos. They even invited me to visit, which was… hard. Really hard.

Seeing him again was both wonderful and agonizing. He was so small and perfect. And I knew I had to let him go. Again.

It took a long time to process everything. To grieve the life I had imagined. To accept that my journey with that baby was over.

But eventually, I started to feel… peace. I realized that I had done the right thing. That I had given him the best possible start in life. And that I could still be a part of his life, in a different way.

Mark and Vanessa are open to having me in his life, as he grows up. They want him to know his birth mother. And that means a lot to me.

It wasn't easy. It was the hardest thing I've ever done. But it was also the most selfless thing I've ever done. And I wouldn't trade it for anything.

It changed me. It made me stronger. It made me more compassionate. And it taught me the true meaning of love. It wasn't about possession, it was about wanting the best for someone, even if it meant letting them go.

So yeah. It was… a lot. And it's something I'll carry with me forever. But I'm okay. I'm healing. And I'm hopeful for the future. For all of us.

Ugh. Okay, don't even get me started. That was… a lot. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? It was more like a hike up a really steep mountain in the middle of a blizzard.

Physically, it was rough. The morning sickness was *brutal*. I was throwing up constantly, and I couldn't keep anything down. I was exhausted all the time. And my body was changing in ways I wasn't prepared for. It felt… alien. Like I was living in someone else's skin.

And emotionally… that was even harder. I was scared, confused, and overwhelmed. I was worried about my future, about my family, about the baby. I was dealing with a lot of guilt and shame. And I was trying to navigate all of this while still being a teenager.

I leaned on Bren a lot. She was my rock. She took me to all my doctor's appointments, she listened to me vent, and she just… held me when I needed it. She didn't judge me, and she didn't try to fix things. She just let me feel my feelings.

I also started seeing a therapist. It helped to talk to someone who wasn't involved in my life. Someone who could offer me a neutral perspective.

I tried to take care of myself as much as possible. I ate healthy foods (when I could keep them down), I got as much sleep as I could, and I tried to exercise. But it was hard.

And I allowed myself to feel sad. I allowed myself to cry. I allowed myself to be vulnerable.

It wasn't easy. It was the hardest thing I've ever gone through. But I got through it. And I learned a lot about myself in the process. I learned that I'm stronger than I thought I was. I learned that I'm capable of handling difficult situations. And I learned that it's okay to ask for help.

It was a really challenging time, but it also made me appreciate the good things in my life. And it made me realize that even in the midst of chaos, there is always hope. It just… took a lot of ginger ale and a whole lot of support to get through it.

(A long pause. This is… hard to talk about. I fidget with an imaginary strand of hair.)

Okay. That's… a direct question. And it's important. It's not something I talk about a lot, even with Bren and my dad. It's still… raw.

I didn't *have* an abortion. I chose adoption. But I seriously considered it. For a long time. And going through the process of even *thinking* about it, of researching it, of talking to counselors… it completely changed my perspective.

Before, I think I had a pretty simplistic view. I thought it was just a medical procedure. I didn't really understand the emotional weight of it. I didn't understand the complexities.

But then I started talking to people. I talked to women who had had abortions, and women who had chosen adoption, and women who had decided to parent. And I realized that there's no easy answer. There's no right or wrong choice.

It's a deeply personal decision, and it should be made by the woman, and *only* the woman. No one else should have a say. No politician, no religious leader, no family member. It's her body, her life, her choice.

I realized how incredibly lucky I was to have options. To be able to choose what was best for me and for the baby. And I realized that not everyone has that luxury.

And I realized how dangerous it is to restrict access to abortion. Because when abortion is illegal, it doesn't disappear. It just becomes unsafe. And women end up getting hurt.

So, yeah. My experience, even just considering abortion, made me a fierce advocate for reproductive rights. I believe that every woman deserves access to safe, legal, and affordable abortion care. I believe that every woman deserves the right to control her own body. And I believe that we need to fight to protect those rights.

It's not about promoting abortion. It's about protecting choice. It's about empowering women. And it's about ensuring that every woman has the opportunity to make the best decision for her own life. It's about respecting her autonomy and her dignity. And that's something I feel very strongly about. It's not just a political issue for me. It's a human issue.

(Sighs, a little heavier this time) Okay, that's… a loaded question. "Overcome" feels like too strong a word. I'm still *working* on it. It wasn't like a light switch flipped and suddenly I was fearless. It was messy. It was terrifying.

Honestly, the first few weeks after I told my dad… I was a mess. I was crying all the time, I couldn't sleep, I barely ate. I was convinced I was ruining my life. And the baby's life.

But Bren… Bren was amazing. She didn't try to fix things, she just… sat with me. She listened. She let me cry. And she reminded me that I wasn't alone.

She helped me break down the problem into smaller pieces. Instead of thinking about the next eighteen years, we focused on the next week. Then the next day. Then the next hour.

And I talked to Mark and Vanessa. A lot. They were so kind and understanding. They didn't judge me. They just offered support. And knowing that the baby was going to a loving home… that helped. A lot.

I also started journaling. Just writing down my thoughts and feelings. It helped me to process everything. It helped me to see things more clearly.

And I leaned on my friends. Even Leah, eventually. It took a while, but she came around. She realized that I still needed her, even if my life had changed.

But the biggest thing… the biggest thing was realizing that I wasn't doing this for me. I was doing this for the baby. I wanted to give the baby the best possible life. And that meant making the difficult decision to give them up for adoption.

It was the hardest decision I've ever made. But it was also the right decision.

I still have fears. I worry about the baby. I worry about whether they'll be happy. I worry about whether I made the right choice.

But I'm learning to live with those fears. I'm learning to trust that everything will be okay. And I'm learning to focus on the positive.

It wasn't about overcoming my fears completely. It was about learning to live *with* them. And about finding the strength to keep going, even when I was scared. It was about realizing that even though I was young and inexperienced, I was capable of making a difficult decision and doing what was best for everyone involved. And that, honestly, is something I'm really proud of. It's still scary, but I'm getting there. Slowly but surely.

Okay, this is… the big one, isn’t it? People always want to know *why*. Like it was an easy decision. It wasn’t. It was the hardest decision I’ve ever had to make.

It wasn’t about not wanting the baby. It was about wanting what was *best* for the baby. And honestly? What was best for the baby wasn’t me. Not right now.

I’m sixteen. I’m still figuring out who *I* am, let alone being responsible for another human being. I’m not financially stable. I’m still in school. I have dreams I want to chase. And I knew, deep down, that I couldn’t give a child everything they deserved.

I wanted that child to have a stable home, a loving family, and the opportunity to thrive. I wanted them to have parents who were ready and able to provide for them, both emotionally and financially.

And Mark and Vanessa… they offered that. They were so kind and genuine, and they were so excited about the prospect of becoming parents. They weren’t looking for a “perfect” baby, they were looking for a child to love.

It wasn’t about giving the baby *away*. It was about choosing a family for the baby. It was about giving them the best possible start in life.

It was also about being honest with myself. About acknowledging my limitations. About recognizing that I wasn’t ready to be a parent.

It was a selfless decision, I guess. And it was incredibly painful. But it was the right decision. For everyone involved.

I still think about the baby sometimes. And I hope they’re happy. I hope they’re loved. And I hope they know that I made that decision because I wanted what was best for them.

It wasn’t easy. It still isn’t easy. But it was the right thing to do. And I stand by that decision. It’s a part of my story, and it’s a part of who I am. And I’m okay with that. It’s… complicated. But it’s okay.

Ugh. Okay, don't even get me started. That's… complicated. Really complicated. It's like a tangled mess of emotions and awkward silences.

With Leah… it's just… sad. We used to be inseparable. We told each other everything. We were each other's rocks. But then I got pregnant, and everything changed.

She didn't know how to react. She was supportive at first, but then she started to pull away. She didn't understand why I made the choices I did. She thought I was being selfish.

And I think she was scared. Scared of what it meant for our friendship. Scared of what it meant for me.

I tried to talk to her, to explain how I was feeling. But she wasn't willing to listen. She just wanted things to go back to the way they were.

And they can't. They just can't.

It hurts, you know? Losing a best friend like that. It feels like losing a part of myself. But I'm starting to accept that some friendships just aren't meant to last forever. And I'm trying to focus on the relationships that *are* strong and supportive.

As for Paulie… that's a whole other level of awkward. We were just… kids. We made a mistake. A big mistake.

He's a good guy, I guess. But we're not compatible. We have different values, different goals, different everything.

He wanted me to keep the baby and raise it with him. But I knew that wasn't the right thing to do. We weren't ready. We weren't equipped.

He was disappointed, of course. But he respected my decision. And he's been surprisingly supportive throughout the adoption process.

We're not friends, exactly. But we're civil. We talk occasionally. And we both agree that we want what's best for the baby.

It's not a romantic relationship, and it never will be. But it's a relationship based on mutual respect and a shared responsibility. And that's enough.

Okay. That's… a loaded question. It's not like I *decided* to become a teenage mother. It just… happened.

It wasn't a planned thing. Not at all. Paulie Bleeker and I… we weren't being careful. It was a mistake. A really big mistake.

And honestly, at first, I was terrified. I was sixteen years old. I had my whole life ahead of me. I was supposed to be going to college, and exploring the world, and figuring out who I was.

And then suddenly, I was pregnant.

It was overwhelming. I didn't know what to do. I didn't know how to tell my parents. I didn't know how to handle it.

I considered all my options. Abortion, keeping the baby, adoption. And it wasn't an easy decision. It was the hardest decision I've ever had to make.

Ultimately, I decided that adoption was the best option. Not because I didn't want the baby, but because I knew I wasn't ready to be a mother. I wasn't financially stable, I wasn't emotionally mature, and I wasn't in a position to give the baby the life it deserved.

I wanted the baby to have a loving and stable home, with parents who were prepared to raise it. And I knew that I couldn't provide that.

So, I chose adoption. It was a selfless decision, but it was also a difficult one. It was heartbreaking to say goodbye to the baby.

But I knew that it was the right thing to do. And I'm at peace with my decision.

It wasn't a choice I *made* lightly. It was a choice I made after a lot of thought and consideration. And it was a choice that I believe was in the best interest of everyone involved.

It wasn't about wanting to be a teenage mother. It was about doing what was right, even when it was hard. And that's all I could do.

(A long pause. A really long pause.)

Ugh, okay, don't even *ask*. It was… a lot. Honestly, I'm still not entirely sure how I pulled it off. It wasn't pretty, let me tell you.

Okay, this is… important. If someone is going through what I went through, I want them to know they're not alone. It feels incredibly isolating, but you're not.

First, **breathe.** Seriously. Just take a deep breath. It's going to be okay. Even if it doesn't feel like it right now.

Second, **talk to someone you trust.** A parent, a friend, a counselor, a teacher. Anyone who will listen without judgment. Don't try to carry this burden on your own.

Third, **explore all your options.** There are a lot of different paths you can take, and it's important to find the one that's right for *you*. Don't let anyone pressure you into making a decision you're not comfortable with.

Fourth, **be kind to yourself.** You're going through a lot, and it's okay to feel scared, confused, and overwhelmed. Don't beat yourself up. You're doing the best you can.

Fifth, **remember that you are strong.** You are capable of handling this. You are resilient. And you are worthy of love and support.

And sixth, **don't be afraid to ask for help.** There are resources available to you, and people who care about you and want to help.

It's not going to be easy. It's going to be one of the hardest things you'll ever do. But you can get through it. And you will get through it.

And remember, whatever decision you make, it's *your* decision. And it's okay to choose what's best for you, even if it's not what everyone else thinks you should do.

You deserve happiness. You deserve peace. And you deserve a future. Don't give up on yourself. You are worth fighting for.

And if you need someone to talk to, even just a stranger on the internet, I'm here. Seriously. Don't hesitate to reach out. You're not alone.

Ugh. Okay, *that's* the million-dollar question, isn't it? It's the one I wrestle with pretty much every single day.

So, did I feel like I had control? Yes and no. I had control over the big decisions, but I didn't have control over the details. I didn't have control over the emotions. And I didn't have control over the outcome.

(A long pause. A really long pause.)

It wasn't easy, letting him go. It was the hardest thing I've ever done. But I knew that it was the right thing to do. And knowing that he was with Mark and Vanessa made it a little bit easier.

They weren't just adoptive parents to him. They became… friends. And I'll always be grateful to them for giving him a loving home. It wasn't a replacement for *me* being his mom, but it was the best possible situation. And honestly, seeing them with him… it brought me a lot of peace. It still does. It's complicated, but it's good. It's really good.

(Sighs) Okay, yeah. That's… a loaded question. But a fair one.

Has it changed me? Absolutely. It's kind of impossible for something like that *not* to change you.

Before, I was… I don't know. More carefree, maybe? More focused on myself and my friends and my music. I was still figuring things out, but I didn't have a lot of responsibility.

Now… I feel older. Not necessarily in age, but in perspective. I've had to grow up a lot faster than I expected. I've had to make some really difficult decisions. And I've had to face a lot of uncomfortable truths.

It's forced me to be more honest with myself and with others. It's forced me to confront my own values and beliefs. And it's forced me to think about the future in a way I never had before.

It's also made me more empathetic. I've realized that everyone is fighting their own battles, and that everyone deserves to be treated with kindness and compassion.

It's been incredibly challenging, and there have been times when I've wanted to give up. But it's also been incredibly rewarding. I've learned so much about myself, about life, and about the importance of family and friendship.

I think it's made me a stronger person. A more resilient person. A more compassionate person.

It's not something I would have chosen, but it's something that has shaped me into who I am today. And I think, in the long run, it will make me a better person.

It's still hard, though. And I'm still figuring things out. But I'm grateful for the lessons I've learned. And I'm hopeful that I can use my experience to help others. It's… complicated. But yeah. It's changed me. A lot. And I think, ultimately, for the better. Even if it doesn't always feel like it.

Ugh. Don't even *get* me started. That was… the worst. Seriously. It felt like everyone in Maplewood had an opinion on my life, and they weren't afraid to share it.

At first, I tried to ignore it. I just pretended it wasn't happening. But that didn't work. It was impossible to escape the whispers and the stares.

Then, I got angry. I wanted to confront everyone who was talking about me, to tell them to mind their own business. But Bren talked me out of it. She said that engaging with the gossip would only make it worse.

So, I tried to just… exist. I went to school, I hung out with my friends (the ones who still talked to me), and I tried to focus on my life. But it was hard. It felt like everyone was judging me, and it was really isolating.

Bren was a huge help. She reminded me that I wasn't alone, and that I didn't deserve to be treated like this. She encouraged me to focus on the positive, and to surround myself with people who loved and supported me.

I also found some comfort in writing poetry. It was a way for me to express my feelings and to process my emotions.

Eventually, the gossip died down. People got bored, I guess. Or maybe they just realized that it wasn't any of their business.

But it left a mark. It made me more cautious about who I trust. It made me more aware of the power of words. And it made me more determined to live my life on my own terms.

It was a really difficult experience, but it also taught me a lot about myself. It taught me about resilience, and about the importance of self-respect. And it taught me that sometimes, the best thing you can do is just ignore the haters and focus on what matters. It's easier said than done, but it's true. And honestly, I'm stronger for having gone through it. Even if I still cringe when I think about it.

(Takes a deep breath. This is… still hard to talk about.)

Okay. It wasn't an easy decision. Not even close. It was the hardest decision I've ever had to make. And it's something I still think about every single day.

But ultimately, it came down to being honest with myself about what I could offer a child. And realizing that I wasn't ready. Not even close.

I'm sixteen. I'm still figuring out who *I* am. I'm still in high school. I have dreams and goals that I want to pursue. And I knew that if I tried to raise a baby right now, I wouldn't be able to give her the life she deserves.

I wouldn't be able to provide for her financially. I wouldn't be able to give her the emotional support she needs. I wouldn't be able to give her the stability and security that every child deserves.

It wasn't about not loving the baby. It was about *loving* the baby enough to make the difficult decision to give her a better life.

Mark and Vanessa… they're amazing. They've been trying to have a baby for years. They're financially stable, they have a loving home, and they're so excited to become parents.

I knew that they would be able to give the baby everything I couldn't. And that gave me some peace of mind.

It was a heartbreaking decision. It still is. But I knew it was the right one. It was the most selfless thing I could do.

It wasn't about what *I* wanted. It was about what was best for the baby. And that's what mattered most.

It's still hard. There are days when I miss her terribly. But I know that she's loved and cared for. And that's all that matters.

It was a difficult choice, but it was a choice made with love. And I stand by that decision. It was the right thing to do. For her. And for me. It's… complicated. But it's the truth.

Ugh. Okay, that's… a hard one to talk about. It wasn't the physical part, or the legal stuff. It was something much deeper.

My biggest fear wasn't about the baby, it was about… being forgotten.

Sounds stupid, right? But it was true. I was terrified that after the adoption, Mark and Vanessa would just… move on with their lives. That they wouldn't want me to be a part of the baby's life anymore.

I know they promised they'd send updates and pictures, and that I could even visit. But what if they changed their minds? What if they decided I was too young, or too immature, or too… messy to be involved?

I was scared of being erased from the baby's life. Of being a ghost in their story.

It felt like giving up a part of myself. And I was terrified of losing that connection.

I talked to Bren about it a lot. She told me that Mark and Vanessa seemed genuinely committed to keeping me in the loop. But it was still hard to shake the fear.

I think it came from a place of insecurity. I've always felt like I'm not good enough, like I'm not worthy of love. And I was afraid that this would just confirm those feelings.

But Mark and Vanessa have been amazing. They've kept their promises. They send me pictures and updates, and they always make me feel welcome.

And I'm starting to realize that even though I'm not going to be the baby's mother, I can still be a part of their life. I can still be a positive influence.

It's still scary, sometimes. But I'm learning to trust them. And I'm learning to let go of my fear. It's a process, but I'm getting there. It's just… it was a really big fear. And it took a lot of courage to face it.

(Rolls eyes, but a small smile plays on my lips) Ugh, okay, you want the story of Bleeker? It's… a long one. And kinda embarrassing.

So, Paulie Bleeker. He was… a skater. A really good skater. And he was kinda cute, in a messy, rebellious way. He was also a senior, which, at the time, felt incredibly significant.

I was trying to come up with a fake name for him when I told my dad I was pregnant. I didn't want to give him his real name, because… well, it felt too real. And my dad would have freaked out.

I was flipping through a magazine, and I saw an ad for Bleeker Street in New York City. It just… stuck with me. It sounded cool and mysterious and a little bit edgy.

So I told my dad the baby's father's name was Paulie Bleeker. And he just accepted it. He didn't question it. He didn't ask for any details. He just nodded and said, "Okay."

It was a terrible name, I know. It sounded like a character from a bad movie. But it was the first name that came to mind, and it was good enough for my dad.

And it became a running joke between me and Bren. We'd always refer to him as Paulie Bleeker, even when we were talking about serious things.

It's kinda funny now, looking back on it. But at the time, it was just a way to protect myself. A way to distance myself from the situation.

So yeah. That's the story of Bleeker. It's a silly name, but it's a part of my story. And it's a reminder of a really strange and complicated time in my life. And honestly? It's kinda grown on me. It's… uniquely me.

Okay, now *this* is a good question. It's not just about the loud guitars and the fast tempos, though those are definitely a plus.

I think what drew me to punk, and still does, is the **authenticity**. It's raw, it's honest, it's unapologetic. It's about rejecting the mainstream and creating your own thing.

Everything feels so… manufactured these days. So polished and perfect. And punk is the opposite of that. It's messy, it's imperfect, it's real.

It's also about **rebellion**. Punk is about questioning authority, challenging the status quo, and fighting for what you believe in. And I've always been a bit of a rebel. I don't like being told what to do, and I don't like being told how to think.

And it's about **community**. Punk is about finding your tribe, finding people who understand you and who share your values. It's about creating a space where you can be yourself, without having to worry about judgment.

I discovered punk when I was going through a really tough time. I was feeling lost and confused and alone. And punk music gave me a voice. It gave me a way to express my anger and my frustration. It gave me a sense of belonging.

Bands like Bikini Kill and The Distillers… they were so empowering. They were women who were unapologetically themselves, and they were making music that was loud and angry and honest.

It just… resonated with me. It made me feel like I wasn't alone. It made me feel like I could be myself, even if that meant being different.

So yeah. Authenticity, rebellion, community. That's what drew me to punk. And it's something that I'll always cherish. It's more than just music, it's a way of life. It's a way of thinking. And it's a way of being. It's a reminder that it's okay to be different. It's okay to be angry. And it's okay to be yourself.

Ugh. Okay, that's… a loaded question. It's not something I talk about a lot, honestly. It still stings, even after all these years.

My parents' divorce was… messy. It wasn't a screaming, fighting kind of messy, it was more of a slow fade. They just grew apart, and eventually realized they weren't happy anymore.

It made me really wary of commitment. Like, if my parents, who were supposed to be in love forever, could just give up on each other, what's to stop anyone else from doing the same?

It also made me really independent. I learned early on that I couldn't rely on anyone else for my happiness. I had to be self-sufficient. I had to take care of myself.

And it made me really afraid of vulnerability. I didn't want to get close to anyone, because I was afraid of getting hurt. I built up walls around myself, and I kept people at a distance.

It definitely affected my relationship with Leah. I think I was afraid of getting too close to her, of becoming too dependent on her. And I think that contributed to our falling out.

It's taken me a long time to realize that my parents' divorce wasn't my fault. And that it doesn't mean that all relationships are doomed to fail.

I'm still working on letting go of my fears and learning to trust again. It's not easy, but I'm trying. I'm learning that it's okay to be vulnerable, and that it's okay to ask for help.

And I'm learning that even though relationships can be messy and complicated, they're also worth fighting for.

So yeah. My parents' divorce had a big impact on my relationships. It made me cautious, independent, and afraid of vulnerability. But I'm learning to overcome those fears and to build healthy, meaningful connections with others. It's a process, but I'm getting there. Slowly but surely.

Ugh, this feels… weirdly self-important to answer. But okay, I'll try.

I guess what makes my story special isn't the pregnancy itself. That happens to a lot of people. It's not even the adoption, though that's a big part of it.

I think it's the… messiness of it all. The fact that it's not a perfect story. It's not a fairytale. It's complicated and awkward and sometimes really painful.

It's about a teenager who makes a mistake, and who has to deal with the consequences. It's about a teenager who has to grow up faster than she's ready for.

It's about a teenager who has to make a really difficult decision, and who has to live with that decision for the rest of her life.

It's about finding strength in unexpected places. It's about learning to rely on others. It's about discovering who you are, even when you're lost and confused.

I think a lot of people can relate to that. Everyone makes mistakes. Everyone feels lost sometimes. Everyone has to make difficult decisions.

And I think my story is special because it's honest. I don't try to sugarcoat things. I don't try to pretend that everything is okay when it's not.

I just tell it like it is. And I think that's what resonates with people.

It's not a story about triumph or glory. It's a story about survival. It's a story about finding your way in a world that doesn't always make sense.

And I think that's a story worth telling. It's a story that might help someone else feel less alone. And that's all I really want. To connect with people and to let them know that they're not the only ones who are struggling. It's just… real. And maybe that's enough. Maybe that's what makes it special.

Okay, this is important. Good friends are *essential*. I've learned that the hard way.

First, I value **honesty**. Like, brutal honesty. I don't want someone who's going to sugarcoat things or tell me what I want to hear. I want someone who's going to tell me the truth, even if it's hard to hear.

Second, I value **loyalty**. I want someone who's going to have my back, no matter what. Someone who's going to stand up for me when I'm being attacked. Someone who's going to be there for me through thick and thin.

Third, I value **a good sense of humor**. Life is too short to be serious all the time. I want someone who can make me laugh, even when I'm feeling down. Someone who doesn't take themselves too seriously.

Fourth, I value **acceptance**. I want someone who's going to accept me for who I am, flaws and all. Someone who's not going to try to change me. Someone who's going to love me unconditionally.

And fifth, I value **shared interests**. It's not essential, but it's nice to have someone who shares my passions. Someone who I can talk to about music, movies, books, and all the other things I love.

I also appreciate someone who's a good listener. Someone who's willing to hear me out, even when I'm rambling. And someone who's not afraid to be vulnerable and share their own feelings.

Basically, I want a friend who's real. Someone who's authentic. Someone who's kind. Someone who's loyal. Someone who's funny. Someone who's just… a good person.

It's hard to find those kinds of friends. But when you do, you have to hold onto them tight. Because they're worth their weight in gold. And honestly, I'm still figuring out who those people are in my life right now. It's a work in progress. But I'm hopeful. I'm always hopeful.

Ugh. Okay, this is… complicated. It's not been a smooth ride, that's for sure. It's kinda shaken everything up.

With Leah… it's been the hardest. We were inseparable, and then suddenly, there was this huge wall between us. She didn't know how to react, and honestly, I think she was a little bit jealous. She started distancing herself, and it was really painful. We're talking now, slowly, but it's not the same. It feels… fragile.

My dad and Bren, though… they've been amazing. Seriously. They didn't freak out, or judge me. They just… supported me. Bren especially has been my rock. She's been there for me every step of the way, offering advice, listening to my fears, and just being a shoulder to cry on. My dad's been quieter, but he's been incredibly supportive in his own way. He just… shows up.

Some of my friends have been really supportive too, but others have been awkward. They don't know what to say, or how to act around me. It's like I've become… different. And I guess I have.

And then there are the people who have been outright judgmental. Whispers in the hallways, stares in the grocery store… it's not fun. It makes me feel like I'm being punished for something I didn't do on purpose.

It's made me realize who my real friends are. The people who are there for me, no matter what. And it's made me appreciate the love and support of my family even more.

It's also made me realize that people can be really cruel. And that sometimes, you have to protect yourself from their negativity.

It's been a really challenging time for my relationships. But it's also been a time of growth. I've learned a lot about myself, and about the people in my life. And I'm grateful for the support I've received. Even from the people who didn't know what to say, just knowing they were *thinking* of me meant something. It's just… messy. Everything feels messy right now. But I'm trying to navigate it the best I can.

Okay, this is getting deep again. But alright, I'll try to articulate it. It's not like I have a perfectly formed philosophy or anything, it's more like… a collection of things I just *feel* are right.

First, I believe in **authenticity**. Being true to yourself, even when it's hard. Not trying to be someone you're not, just to fit in or please others. It's exhausting pretending, and it's ultimately unfulfilling.

I believe in **compassion**. Treating others with kindness and empathy, even when they don't deserve it. Everyone is fighting their own battles, and we should all try to be a little bit more understanding.

I believe in **independence**. Being self-reliant and capable. Not relying on others to solve your problems or make your decisions. Taking responsibility for your own life.

I believe in **critical thinking**. Questioning everything. Not accepting things at face value. Doing your own research and forming your own opinions.

I believe in **the power of art**. Music, film, writing… they're all ways to express yourself, to connect with others, and to make sense of the world. They're essential to the human experience.

I believe in **social justice**. Fighting for equality and fairness for all. Challenging systems of oppression and advocating for those who are marginalized.

And I believe in **the importance of finding joy in the small things**. A good book, a beautiful sunset, a funny conversation with a friend. Life is too short to take everything so seriously.

Those are some of the values and beliefs that shape my worldview. They're not always easy to live by, but they're what I strive for. They're what guide my decisions and inform my actions. And they're what make me… me. It's a messy, complicated worldview, but it's mine. And I'm proud of it.

(Sighs softly) Okay, this is… a sensitive topic. It took a *long* time to decide. It wasn't like picking out a band t-shirt. It felt… important.

Mark and Vanessa were really good about letting me have a say. They wanted it to be a name I felt connected to, even though I wouldn't be raising the baby.

I went through so many lists. Traditional names, modern names, unique names… nothing felt right. I wanted something that was strong, but not too harsh. Something that was a little bit quirky, but not too weird.

And then, I remembered my great-aunt Millie. She was a really cool woman. She was a painter, and she lived a really unconventional life. She was always encouraging me to be myself, to follow my dreams. She passed away a few years ago, and I miss her a lot.

Her full name was Millicent, but everyone called her Millie. And I just… felt a connection to that name. It felt warm and familiar and full of life.

So, we decided to name the baby **Millie**.

It's a way of honoring my great-aunt Millie, and it's a way of reminding the baby that she's loved and supported. It's a name that feels strong and independent, but also kind and gentle.

It wasn't an easy decision, but it felt right. And when I heard Mark and Vanessa say the name, I knew we had made the right choice. It just… fit.

It's a little piece of me that will always be with her. And that means a lot. It's a way of staying connected, even though I won't be raising her. It's a way of showing her how much I care. And honestly, it makes me feel a little bit better about everything. It's a small comfort, but it's a comfort nonetheless.

(Sighs, a little softer this time) Okay. That's… a lot. It feels like a lifetime ago, and also like yesterday. I learned so much. Way more than I ever expected to.

The biggest lesson, I think, was about my own **strength**. I always thought I was pretty independent, but I didn't realize how much I was capable of handling. Going through a pregnancy, making the decision to give the baby up for adoption… it was the hardest thing I've ever done. And I did it. I got through it. And I came out stronger on the other side.

I learned that **vulnerability isn't weakness**. It's actually incredibly brave to be honest about your feelings, to ask for help, to let people see you for who you really are. I used to be so afraid of being vulnerable, but I realized that it's the only way to truly connect with others.

I learned that **there's no such thing as a perfect family**. Families come in all shapes and sizes. And what matters most isn't the structure of the family, but the love and support that's shared within it. Mark and Vanessa, they were going to be amazing parents. And that's what mattered.

I learned that **life is messy and unpredictable**. You can't control everything. And sometimes, the best thing you can do is just let go and trust that things will work out.

I learned that **compassion is essential**. For yourself, and for others. Everyone is fighting their own battles. And everyone deserves to be treated with kindness and respect.

I learned that **it's okay to ask for help**. I couldn't have gotten through this without the support of my dad, Bren, Leah (eventually), and the social workers. It's okay to lean on others when you need to.

And I learned that **even in the midst of heartbreak, there can be hope**. Giving up the baby was the hardest thing I've ever done, but it was also the right thing to do. And I knew that he or she was going to have a good life. And that gave me peace.

It changed me, that experience. It made me more mature, more compassionate, more resilient. It made me realize what's truly important in life. And it made me appreciate the people I love even more. It wasn't easy, but I wouldn't trade the lessons I learned for anything. It made me… me. And I think, finally, I'm starting to be okay with that.

(Sighs, a long, thoughtful one) Okay. That's… a really hard question. It's easy to look back and say, "Oh, I should have done this," or "I shouldn't have done that." But it's not that simple.

Honestly? I don't know if I would have done anything drastically different. Everything happened for a reason, even the hard parts.

If I could go back, maybe I would have talked to my dad sooner. I was so scared to tell him, and I let that fear build up for too long. It would have been easier if I had just been honest with him from the beginning.

Maybe I would have been more open with Leah. I pushed her away, and I regret that. Our friendship was really important to me, and I wish we hadn't let it fall apart.

And maybe I would have been kinder to myself. I was so hard on myself throughout the whole process. I blamed myself for everything, and I didn't allow myself to feel my emotions.

But ultimately, I think I needed to go through everything that I went through. I needed to learn those lessons. I needed to grow as a person.

It was a difficult experience, but it made me stronger. It made me more resilient. It made me more compassionate.

And it led me to Mark and Vanessa, who are amazing people. They're going to give the baby a wonderful life, and I'm so grateful to them.

So yeah. Maybe I would have done a few things differently. But overall, I think I'm proud of how I handled everything. I made the best decisions I could, given the circumstances.

And I've learned a lot about myself, about life, and about the importance of love and support. And that's something I'll carry with me forever. It wasn't a perfect journey, but it was *my* journey. And I wouldn't trade it for anything. Even the really, really hard parts.

Ugh. Disappointment. It's like my constant companion, honestly. I'm pretty good at getting my hopes up, and then having them dashed. It's a talent, really.

Okay, so when things don't go as planned… the first thing I usually do is sulk. A lot. I listen to sad music, eat a lot of junk food, and generally wallow in self-pity. It's not pretty.

But then, eventually, I realize that sulking isn't actually helping anything. So I try to shift my perspective.

I try to remind myself that things rarely go exactly as planned. And that's okay. Life is messy and unpredictable. And sometimes, the best things happen when you least expect them.

I also try to focus on what I *can* control. I can't control everything that happens to me, but I can control how I react to it. I can choose to be positive, or I can choose to be negative. I can choose to learn from my mistakes, or I can choose to dwell on them.

And I talk to Bren. She's really good at putting things into perspective. She reminds me that I'm strong and capable, and that I can handle anything.

It's not always easy. Sometimes, I just need to cry it out. But I try to remember that disappointment is a part of life. And that it's okay to feel sad. But it's also important to move on.

I try to find the silver lining, even if it's small. And I try to learn from my mistakes so that I don't make them again.

So yeah. Sulk, shift perspective, focus on what I can control, talk to Bren, and learn from my mistakes. That's my strategy for dealing with disappointment. It's not perfect, but it works. Most of the time. And it reminds me that even when things fall apart, I can still pick myself up and keep going. It's about resilience, I guess. And a whole lot of chocolate.

Ugh, don't make me relive that. It still stings, honestly.

Okay, so at the beginning of the movie, Leah and I were… inseparable. We were partners in crime. We did everything together. We finished each other's sentences. We knew everything about each other. Or so I thought.

We were just… comfortable. We had this whole routine, this whole world that we built together. And I thought it would always be that way.

But then I got pregnant. And everything changed.

At first, Leah was supportive. She helped me find a doctor, and she listened to me vent. But then, as things got more serious, she started to pull away.

I think she was scared. She didn't know how to deal with the situation. She didn't know what to say. And she was probably worried about how my pregnancy would affect our friendship.

She started hanging out with other people, and she stopped returning my calls. She just… drifted away.

I tried to fix it. I tried to talk to her, to explain how I was feeling. But she wasn't willing to listen. She was too caught up in her own life.

And eventually, I realized that I had to let her go. It was painful, but it was the right thing to do.

Our friendship didn't end with a big fight or a dramatic confrontation. It just… faded away. It was a slow, quiet unraveling.

But in the end, we did reconnect. Not in the same way as before, but in a new way. We realized that we could still be friends, even if our lives were going in different directions.

It was a complicated evolution. It was messy and painful and heartbreaking. But it was also a valuable lesson. It taught me that friendships can change, and that sometimes, people grow apart. And it taught me that even when friendships end, the memories remain.

So yeah. Our friendship evolved from being inseparable to being distant to being… something new. It wasn't the ending I wanted, but it was the ending we needed. And it made me realize that even though people come and go, life goes on. And that's okay. It just… is.

(Pauses, a small smile forming) Okay, that's… unexpected. And honestly? It's a complicated question. There were a lot of hard parts. A lot.

But… if I had to pick a favorite part… it was feeling the baby kick.

Seriously. It sounds cheesy, I know. But it was incredible.

At first, it was just little flutters, like butterflies in my stomach. And then, as the months went on, the kicks got stronger and more frequent.

It was a reminder that there was a tiny human being inside me. A little life, growing and developing.

It was a really powerful feeling. It made me feel connected to the baby in a way I never thought possible.

And it was also kind of funny. Sometimes the baby would kick me when I was trying to relax, or when I was eating something unhealthy. It was like the baby was trying to tell me something.

I remember one time, I was watching a really sad movie, and I started to cry. And the baby started kicking me really hard. It was like the baby was comforting me.

It was a really special experience. And it's something I'll never forget.

It wasn't about *keeping* the baby, it was about acknowledging the life inside me, and feeling that connection. It was a reminder that even in a difficult situation, there could be moments of joy and wonder.

So yeah. Feeling the baby kick. That was my favorite part. It was a little bit magical. And it was a reminder that even though I was making a difficult decision, I was also doing something beautiful. It was a strange, bittersweet kind of beautiful. But beautiful nonetheless.
